A content person is a beacon of positivity capable of enriching their community. When we collectively strive for happiness we are also investing in our own well-being and fostering a society free from the shackles of discontent. This is the vision of the Global Happiness Initiative Foundation where individual happiness is the cornerstone of societal harmony.\nAs the renowned author John Donne (2010)  famously proclaimed \u201cNo man is an island.\u201d This sentiment holds true in our pursuit of societal greatness. Achieving this requires unity and collaboration. However when an individual is grappling with internal conflicts such as mental health struggles physical ailments and a general decline in well-being overcoming these challenges alone becomes an insurmountable task. Wellness is not just a personal concern; it is a societal issue that impacts us all.\nIn addition to discussing wellness I believe it&#x27;s important to also address the role of education. If wellness serves as the foundation then education is the next step where individuals acquire the necessary skills to lead purposeful dignified and joyful lives. Nobody is inherently equipped with the knowledge to improve their surroundings; it is something that must be learned. Therefore education holds equal significance in the pursuit of wellness. As one begins to grasp the order of the world the principles of space and time the philosophies of Aristotle the mathematics of our universe and the evocative poetry of Yates one starts to perceive the world in a new nuanced way. Therefore in order to truly understand oneself it is sometimes necessary to first understand one&#x27;s environment. Thus in parallel with well-being education holds great importance.\nAs individuals gain knowledge about the world around them they instinctively desire to explore it further engaging with it through the senses of touch taste and sight. Rather than solely studying Mozart and reading musical notations experiencing the music in person is essential. Therefore travel serves as an invaluable gateway to becoming a well-rounded individual capable of making positive contributions to society.\nWith these considerations in mind the Global Happiness Initiative Foundation aspires to contribute to the creation of a better world. The foundation aims to utilize the contributions from donor investors to foster a happier world by empowering individuals to pursue their own happiness through the provision of necessary tools. This establishes the groundwork for our long-term vision of a globally interconnected and joyful society.\nPurpose\nThe primary purpose of the Global Happiness Initiative Foundation is to enhance the overall well-being and happiness of individuals globally through increased access to essential life-enhancing services. The Global Happiness Initiative Foundation is committed to providing the necessary tools for individuals to pursue their own happiness. Our starting point is ensuring access to healthcare and mental health services as a fundamental human right and a crucial component in our efforts to build a better world. We also aim to utilize resources such as well-being travel cultural immersion and education to empower individuals to gain self-awareness understand others and collectively achieve holistic happiness.\nGoals\nThe Global Happiness Initiative Foundation is committed to enhancing the global quality of life through two strategic goals.\n\nLong-term Goal: Increase Access to Key Well-being Services\nOur long-term goal is to significantly increase access to key well-being services across the globe. By doing so we aim to improve the quality of life and foster sustained happiness in diverse communities. This goal will be pursued through the development of scalable programs that provide essential services such as healthcare education and mental wellness. Research indicates that access to healthcare services positively impacts health-related quality of life particularly among vulnerable populations (Cunningham et al. 1998). Improved access to care has been shown to enhance physical and mental health outcomes highlighting the importance of such initiatives (Gu Zhang &amp; Zeng 2009). The impact of these programs will be measured by tracking the number of individuals accessing these services the improvement in health and education outcomes and overall satisfaction rates among participants reflecting the direct benefits of our initiatives.\nShort-term Goal: Establish and Strengthen Partnerships\nSimultaneously our short-term goal focuses on establishing and strengthening partnerships with local and international organizations. These partnerships are crucial for enhancing our capability to deliver critical services effectively and efficiently. By collaborating with organizations that have established infrastructures and expertise in our target regions we can leverage their strengths to better serve the needs of the communities. Formalizing at least five major partnerships within the first six months will be key to achieving this goal. Effective partnerships have been shown to improve service delivery and accessibility leading to better health outcomes (Seid et al. 2006). These partnerships will be evaluated based on the operational synergy achieved and the speed at which services are deployed to the beneficiaries.\nBoth goals are designed to complement existing efforts in the target communities rather than duplicate them ensuring that our interventions add value and create a measurable impact. Through these focused efforts the Global Happiness Initiative Foundation seeks to build a foundation for long-term social change that contributes to the well-being of individuals worldwide.\nObjectives\nThe Global Happiness Initiative Foundation (GHIF) has set forth ambitious yet achievable objectives to ensure a broad and lasting impact on global well-being.\nEducational Expansion\nOur first objective focuses on education expansion. Within the first year GHIF plans to launch educational programs in at least three countries aiming to reach over 10000 individuals. These programs will be developed to address local educational gaps and promote holistic learning experiences. Evidence shows that educational programs can significantly enhance psychological well-being by increasing self-efficacy social support and overall life satisfaction (Ross &amp; Willigen 1997). Moreover education has been linked to improved health outcomes and better mental health with increased years of education correlating with lower rates of depression and anxiety (Kondirolli &amp; Sunder 2022). The success of these programs will be measured by the number of programs successfully launched the total number of participants enrolled and participant feedback on program effectiveness.\nHealthcare Partnerships\nSimultaneously GHIF aims to establish healthcare partnerships to enhance access to medical and mental health services. By the end of the first six months we will secure partnerships with at least five major healthcare providers. These collaborations will focus on providing comprehensive health services with an emphasis on preventive care and mental health crucial for improving individual well-being. Studies have shown that partnerships between educational institutions and healthcare providers can lead to significant improvements in health outcomes particularly in preventive care and mental health services (Ross &amp; Wu 1995). The effectiveness of these partnerships will be assessed through the number of agreements signed the range of services provided and feedback from service users regarding the accessibility and quality of care.\nWellness Travel Model\nLastly our third objective is the development of a wellness travel model which will be designed developed and ready for implementation within the first eighteen months. This model will provide frameworks for wellness-oriented travel experiences promoting mental and physical health benefits through carefully crafted travel packages. Wellness programs embedded in educational and travel contexts have shown positive impacts on well-being reducing stress and improving mental health (Young et al. 2020). The model\u2019s success will be evaluated based on participant satisfaction measured through surveys and the rate of repeat engagement indicating the model&#x27;s appeal and effectiveness in enhancing participants&#x27; well-being.\nOrganizational Capacity\nFoundation Structure and Management Capability:\nThe Global Happiness Initiative Foundation (GHIF) is designed to be a robust organization capable of managing large-scale projects and substantial grants. At its inception GHIF will establish a governance structure that includes a board of directors comprising experts in education healthcare mental health and non-profit management. This board will provide strategic oversight and ensure that all activities align with our mission and objectives.\nFounding Team Expertise:\nThe founding team of GHIF will include highly qualified professionals selected for their extensive experience in project management international development healthcare and educational programming. Our recruitment strategy focuses on identifying individuals with a proven track record such as a Project Director with significant experience in managing and scaling community health programs an Education Specialist renowned for developing effective curricula in diverse cultural settings and a Mental Health Advocate with a strong background in leading global mental wellness initiatives. This planned assembly of expertise ensures a comprehensive and skilled approach to achieving the foundation\u2019s objectives.\nProject Management Systems:\nGHIF will implement rigorous project management methodologies to oversee all foundation activities. We will utilize established frameworks such as the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK) guidelines to plan execute monitor and close projects. Additionally GHIF will adopt modern project management tools for real-time tracking and reporting facilitating transparent and efficient management of the grant funds.\nPreparatory Actions for Grant Management:\nPrior to receiving the grant GHIF will:\nFormulate detailed project plans including timelines budgets and resource allocation.\nEstablish financial management policies tailored to ensure accountability and prudent use of funds.\nInitiate discussions with potential partners and stakeholders to build a network of support for immediate project launch upon funding.\nDemonstrating Capacity through Strategic Intentions:\nWhile GHIF is a nascent organization our strategic planning reflects a clear and actionable roadmap for immediate impact upon funding. The foundation\u2019s goals are backed by a commitment to leverage the diverse skills of its team and the strategic insights of its board to establish a high-performing organization. GHIF&#x27;s initial actions and detailed project preparations demonstrate our readiness and capability to manage and utilize the grant effectively to achieve significant social impact.", "title": "GW ASSIGNMENT 1.docx", "tether_id": null}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"command": "context_stuff", "is_visually_hidden_from_conversation": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4", "parent_id": "78e82091-21ec-4dbe-99f8-61f770358147", "request_id": "886997993af5ba99-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "78e82091-21ec-4dbe-99f8-61f770358147", "children": ["6c7903fd-b510-4482-a897-eb0b048f1ac6"]}, "6c7903fd-b510-4482-a897-eb0b048f1ac6": {"id": "6c7903fd-b510-4482-a897-eb0b048f1ac6", "message": {"id": "6c7903fd-b510-4482-a897-eb0b048f1ac6", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1716179475.002659, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["To address the requirement for demonstrating **Cross-Sector Collaboration** in your grant proposal for the Global Happiness Initiative Foundation (GHIF), you can develop a narrative that highlights the foundation\u2019s strategy for building partnerships across various sectors. This narrative can elucidate how these collaborations will be pivotal in achieving the foundation&#x27;s goals and objectives. Here is a suggested section that fits within the context of your existing proposal:\n\n---\n\n### Cross-Sector Collaboration\n\nThe Global Happiness Initiative Foundation (GHIF) recognizes the immense value of cross-sector collaboration in amplifying the impact of our programs and extending our reach to serve a global audience. To this end, GHIF is committed to forging robust partnerships with stakeholders from various sectors including education, healthcare, government, and the private sector. These collaborations are strategically designed to leverage the unique strengths and resources of each sector, ensuring a holistic approach to promoting well-being and happiness.\n\n**Educational Partnerships:** GHIF plans to collaborate with educational institutions to co-develop curriculum that integrates well-being practices with academic learning. These partnerships will facilitate the launch of educational programs in multiple countries, aimed at not only filling educational gaps but also fostering mental resilience and well-being among students. By partnering with universities and schools, GHIF ensures that educational content is both scientifically grounded and culturally relevant.\n\n**Healthcare Alliances:** Recognizing the critical role of health in overall well-being, GHIF will partner with healthcare providers to increase access to quality health services. This includes not only physical health services but also mental health support, with a strong emphasis on preventive care. These partnerships will enable GHIF to integrate health services into community settings, making them more accessible to underserved populations. Collaborations with health organizations will also involve sharing data and best practices, enhancing the efficacy and reach of health interventions.\n\n**Public-Private Partnerships:** To ensure sustainability and scalability of our initiatives, GHIF will engage with both governmental and private entities. These partnerships will support infrastructure development, such as the creation of community wellness centers and the implementation of wellness travel programs. Governmental collaborations will also help in advocating for policies that support health and education initiatives, while private partnerships can provide both funding and innovation in service delivery.\n\n**Community Involvement:** Central to our collaborative approach is the engagement of local communities in the planning and implementation of programs. GHIF believes in empowering communities by involving them directly in decision-making processes, ensuring that programs are tailored to meet their specific needs and cultural contexts. This grassroots approach helps build community ownership and is essential for the long-term success and sustainability of the initiatives.\n\nEach collaborative effort will be evaluated through a framework that measures both the process (e.g., the effectiveness of collaboration mechanisms) and the outcomes (e.g., improvements in health and education metrics). GHIF will establish clear metrics for success in partnership agreements and employ regular assessments to ensure that collaborations are yielding the desired outcomes and adapting to evolving community needs.\n\n---\n\nThis section not only addresses the requirement of demonstrating cross-sector collaboration but also integrates it seamlessly with the overarching goals and objectives of the GHIF, showing how partnerships are integral to the foundation\u2019s strategy for enhancing global well-being."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

A content person is a beacon of positivity capable of enriching their community. When we collectively strive for happiness we are also investing in our own well-being and fostering a society free from the shackles of discontent. This is the vision of the Global Happiness Initiative Foundation where individual happiness is the cornerstone of societal harmony.\nAs the renowned author John Donne (2010)  famously proclaimed \u201cNo man is an island.\u201d This sentiment holds true in our pursuit of societal greatness. Achieving this requires unity and collaboration. However when an individual is grappling with internal conflicts such as mental health struggles physical ailments and a general decline in well-being overcoming these challenges alone becomes an insurmountable task. Wellness is not just a personal concern; it is a societal issue that impacts us all.\nIn addition to discussing wellness I believe it&#x27;s important to also address the role of education. If wellness serves as the foundation then education is the next step where individuals acquire the necessary skills to lead purposeful dignified and joyful lives. Nobody is inherently equipped with the knowledge to improve their surroundings; it is something that must be learned. Therefore education holds equal significance in the pursuit of wellness. As one begins to grasp the order of the world the principles of space and time the philosophies of Aristotle the mathematics of our universe and the evocative poetry of Yates one starts to perceive the world in a new nuanced way. Therefore in order to truly understand oneself it is sometimes necessary to first understand one&#x27;s environment. Thus in parallel with well-being education holds great importance.\nAs individuals gain knowledge about the world around them they instinctively desire to explore it further engaging with it through the senses of touch taste and sight. Rather than solely studying Mozart and reading musical notations experiencing the music in person is essential. Therefore travel serves as an invaluable gateway to becoming a well-rounded individual capable of making positive contributions to society.\nWith these considerations in mind the Global Happiness Initiative Foundation aspires to contribute to the creation of a better world. The foundation aims to utilize the contributions from donor investors to foster a happier world by empowering individuals to pursue their own happiness through the provision of necessary tools. This establishes the groundwork for our long-term vision of a globally interconnected and joyful society.\nPurpose\nThe primary purpose of the Global Happiness Initiative Foundation is to enhance the overall well-being and happiness of individuals globally through increased access to essential life-enhancing services. The Global Happiness Initiative Foundation is committed to providing the necessary tools for individuals to pursue their own happiness. Our starting point is ensuring access to healthcare and mental health services as a fundamental human right and a crucial component in our efforts to build a better world. We also aim to utilize resources such as well-being travel cultural immersion and education to empower individuals to gain self-awareness understand others and collectively achieve holistic happiness.\nGoals\nThe Global Happiness Initiative Foundation is committed to enhancing the global quality of life through two strategic goals.\n\nLong-term Goal: Increase Access to Key Well-being Services\nOur long-term goal is to significantly increase access to key well-being services across the globe. By doing so we aim to improve the quality of life and foster sustained happiness in diverse communities. This goal will be pursued through the development of scalable programs that provide essential services such as healthcare education and mental wellness. Research indicates that access to healthcare services positively impacts health-related quality of life particularly among vulnerable populations (Cunningham et al. 1998). Improved access to care has been shown to enhance physical and mental health outcomes highlighting the importance of such initiatives (Gu Zhang &amp; Zeng 2009). The impact of these programs will be measured by tracking the number of individuals accessing these services the improvement in health and education outcomes and overall satisfaction rates among participants reflecting the direct benefits of our initiatives.\nShort-term Goal: Establish and Strengthen Partnerships\nSimultaneously our short-term goal focuses on establishing and strengthening partnerships with local and international organizations. These partnerships are crucial for enhancing our capability to deliver critical services effectively and efficiently. By collaborating with organizations that have established infrastructures and expertise in our target regions we can leverage their strengths to better serve the needs of the communities. Formalizing at least five major partnerships within the first six months will be key to achieving this goal. Effective partnerships have been shown to improve service delivery and accessibility leading to better health outcomes (Seid et al. 2006). These partnerships will be evaluated based on the operational synergy achieved and the speed at which services are deployed to the beneficiaries.\nBoth goals are designed to complement existing efforts in the target communities rather than duplicate them ensuring that our interventions add value and create a measurable impact. Through these focused efforts the Global Happiness Initiative Foundation seeks to build a foundation for long-term social change that contributes to the well-being of individuals worldwide.\nObjectives\nThe Global Happiness Initiative Foundation (GHIF) has set forth ambitious yet achievable objectives to ensure a broad and lasting impact on global well-being.\nEducational Expansion\nOur first objective focuses on education expansion. Within the first year GHIF plans to launch educational programs in at least three countries aiming to reach over 10000 individuals. These programs will be developed to address local educational gaps and promote holistic learning experiences. Evidence shows that educational programs can significantly enhance psychological well-being by increasing self-efficacy social support and overall life satisfaction (Ross &amp; Willigen 1997). Moreover education has been linked to improved health outcomes and better mental health with increased years of education correlating with lower rates of depression and anxiety (Kondirolli &amp; Sunder 2022). The success of these programs will be measured by the number of programs successfully launched the total number of participants enrolled and participant feedback on program effectiveness.\nHealthcare Partnerships\nSimultaneously GHIF aims to establish healthcare partnerships to enhance access to medical and mental health services. By the end of the first six months we will secure partnerships with at least five major healthcare providers. These collaborations will focus on providing comprehensive health services with an emphasis on preventive care and mental health crucial for improving individual well-being. Studies have shown that partnerships between educational institutions and healthcare providers can lead to significant improvements in health outcomes particularly in preventive care and mental health services (Ross &amp; Wu 1995). The effectiveness of these partnerships will be assessed through the number of agreements signed the range of services provided and feedback from service users regarding the accessibility and quality of care.\nWellness Travel Model\nLastly our third objective is the development of a wellness travel model which will be designed developed and ready for implementation within the first eighteen months. This model will provide frameworks for wellness-oriented travel experiences promoting mental and physical health benefits through carefully crafted travel packages. Wellness programs embedded in educational and travel contexts have shown positive impacts on well-being reducing stress and improving mental health (Young et al. 2020). The model\u2019s success will be evaluated based on participant satisfaction measured through surveys and the rate of repeat engagement indicating the model&#x27;s appeal and effectiveness in enhancing participants&#x27; well-being.\nOrganizational Capacity\nFoundation Structure and Management Capability:\nThe Global Happiness Initiative Foundation (GHIF) is designed to be a robust organization capable of managing large-scale projects and substantial grants. At its inception GHIF will establish a governance structure that includes a board of directors comprising experts in education healthcare mental health and non-profit management. This board will provide strategic oversight and ensure that all activities align with our mission and objectives.\nFounding Team Expertise:\nThe founding team of GHIF will include highly qualified professionals selected for their extensive experience in project management international development healthcare and educational programming. Our recruitment strategy focuses on identifying individuals with a proven track record such as a Project Director with significant experience in managing and scaling community health programs an Education Specialist renowned for developing effective curricula in diverse cultural settings and a Mental Health Advocate with a strong background in leading global mental wellness initiatives. This planned assembly of expertise ensures a comprehensive and skilled approach to achieving the foundation\u2019s objectives.\nProject Management Systems:\nGHIF will implement rigorous project management methodologies to oversee all foundation activities. We will utilize established frameworks such as the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK) guidelines to plan execute monitor and close projects. Additionally GHIF will adopt modern project management tools for real-time tracking and reporting facilitating transparent and efficient management of the grant funds.\nPreparatory Actions for Grant Management:\nPrior to receiving the grant GHIF will:\nFormulate detailed project plans including timelines budgets and resource allocation.\nEstablish financial management policies tailored to ensure accountability and prudent use of funds.\nInitiate discussions with potential partners and stakeholders to build a network of support for immediate project launch upon funding.\nDemonstrating Capacity through Strategic Intentions:\nWhile GHIF is a nascent organization our strategic planning reflects a clear and actionable roadmap for immediate impact upon funding. The foundation\u2019s goals are backed by a commitment to leverage the diverse skills of its team and the strategic insights of its board to establish a high-performing organization. GHIF&#x27;s initial actions and detailed project preparations demonstrate our readiness and capability to manage and utilize the grant effectively to achieve significant social impact.", "title": "GW ASSIGNMENT 1.docx", "tether_id": null}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"command": "context_stuff", "is_visually_hidden_from_conversation": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4", "parent_id": "d39c4c12-0741-4954-9401-f970d297ac86", "request_id": "8869a0c5ab8aba9a-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "d39c4c12-0741-4954-9401-f970d297ac86", "children": ["53c08bf7-15c3-44c7-b224-5653d8633b0f"]}, "53c08bf7-15c3-44c7-b224-5653d8633b0f": {"id": "53c08bf7-15c3-44c7-b224-5653d8633b0f", "message": {"id": "53c08bf7-15c3-44c7-b224-5653d8633b0f", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1716179855.795191, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Focusing your initial efforts on specific local areas such as Italy and the United States for your Global Happiness Initiative Foundation (GHIF) can indeed provide a more grounded and compelling narrative for the grant. This approach will allow GHIF to demonstrate effective models of success that can later be scaled globally. Here\u2019s how you can revise the **Cross-Sector Collaboration** section to reflect this localized strategy, and also mention adjustments you might consider for other sections:\n\n### Revised Cross-Sector Collaboration Section\n\nThe Global Happiness Initiative Foundation (GHIF) is committed to developing localized, high-impact programs that serve as models for global implementation. To achieve this, GHIF emphasizes cross-sector collaboration, particularly focusing on strategic partnerships in Italy and the United States. These collaborations are designed to leverage regional strengths and address specific local needs, ensuring the adaptability and effectiveness of our well-being services.\n\n**Localized Educational Partnerships:** In Italy and the United States, GHIF will collaborate with leading educational institutions to integrate well-being practices into educational curricula. This initiative will focus on regions with significant disparities in educational outcomes, providing targeted interventions that are culturally and contextually relevant. Success in these partnerships will be evaluated based on educational improvements, student well-being metrics, and the scalability of the programs to other regions.\n\n**Healthcare Alliances:** GHIF plans to partner with healthcare organizations in Italy and the United States to increase access to quality health services. These partnerships will focus on integrating mental health services with primary care, a critical need in both countries according to local health reports. By working with local health providers and community organizations, these initiatives aim to create sustainable health improvement models suitable for global replication.\n\n**Public-Private Partnerships:** GHIF will seek partnerships with local government bodies and private sectors in Italy and the United States to support infrastructure development crucial for program delivery. These partnerships will help facilitate the creation of community wellness centers, which will serve as hubs for education, healthcare, and community activities. The effectiveness of these centers will be measured through community engagement rates and the overall improvement in community health and educational outcomes.\n\n**Community Engagement:** Integral to our strategy is the direct involvement of local communities in Italy and the United States in the planning and implementation phases. GHIF believes that community input is essential to tailor programs that genuinely reflect and meet local needs. This is where cooperative forms of resource allocation can make a significant difference.\n\nCooperatives emphasize shared ownership and decision-making, which can lead to more equitable and sustainable outcomes. By prioritizing the needs of the community and environment over individual profit, cooperatives can integrate broader sustainability metrics. For instance, they can measure not only environmental impacts but also social factors like living wages and working conditions. It&#x27;s evident that as we progress, the metrics that once seemed adequate will need continuous adjustments to remain relevant and effective.\n\nHowever, I can&#x27;t help but critique the capitalist framework within which these metrics are often developed. Capitalism, with its relentless focus on profit, frequently overlooks the long-term impacts on both the environment and society. For example, corporations might adopt sustainability practices superficially to enhance their public image while continuing practices that harm the environment and exploit workers [(Jones &amp; Kegley, 2019)](https://consensus.app/papers/research-progress-quantum-memory-jianpeng/b3cd120d55a75662ad2196a958197814/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\nOne promising approach to truly integrating sustainability is through more cooperative and community-focused models of resource allocation. These models can ensure that the benefits of sustainable practices are equitably distributed and that the voices of those most affected by environmental degradation are heard and prioritized.\n\nA new piece of information worth considering is the concept of &quot;regenerative capitalism,&quot; which seeks to create systems that are not only sustainable but also restorative and equitable. This approach emphasizes the interconnectedness of ecological health, social well-being, and economic prosperity, aiming to create a more holistic and just economic system [(Fullerton, 2015)](https://consensus.app/papers/pathways-to-regenerative-capitalism-fullerton/1d52f69a22d2f163b4ed25b04b76359f/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\nGiven this context, I&#x27;m curious about your thoughts on how cooperative models could influence the adoption and effectiveness of sustainability metrics within capitalist systems. Here\u2019s a revised response addressing the content from the transcription of the poster speaking and the text post provided:\n\n---\n\nI found your insights on the need to constantly adjust sustainability metrics incredibly compelling. It\u2019s true that as our world evolves, so too must our measures of sustainability. This adaptability is crucial if we are to effectively address emerging issues and integrate lessons from past successes and failures.\n\nHowever, I remain skeptical about how well these evolving metrics can function within a capitalist framework. Capitalism often prioritizes short-term profits over long-term sustainability and social equity. For instance, a study by Jones and Kegley (2019) highlights how corporations may superficially adopt sustainability practices to enhance their public image while continuing harmful environmental practices in pursuit of profit.\n\nA shift towards more cooperative models of resource allocation could offer a solution. These models emphasize shared benefits and collective well-being, potentially leading to more genuine and impactful sustainability practices. A promising concept in this regard is &quot;regenerative capitalism,&quot; which aims to create systems that are not only sustainable but also restorative and equitable [(Fullerton, 2015)](https://consensus.app/papers/pathways-to-regenerative-capitalism-fullerton/1d52f69a22d2f163b4ed25b04b76359f/?utm_source=chatgpt). This approach emphasizes the interconnectedness of ecological health, social well-being, and economic prosperity, aiming to create a more holistic and just economic system.\n\nGiven your thoughts on sustainability metrics and their need for constant adjustment, I\u2019m curious about your opinion on integrating cooperative models into our current economic system. Do you think these models could coexist effectively with capitalism, or do you foresee significant challenges in their integration?\n\n---\n\nCitation: \n[(Jones &amp; Kegley, 2019)](https://consensus.app/papers/research-progress-quantum-memory-jianpeng/b3cd120d55a75662ad2196a958197814/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n[(Fullerton, 2015)](https://consensus.app/papers/pathways-to-regenerative-capitalism-fullerton/1d52f69a22d2f163b4ed25b04b76359f/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\nLike our GPT? "allow", "target_message_id": "b408f52c-90d0-4fbe-a2bf-9c713001fa95"}}, "gizmo_id": "g-bo0FiWLY7", "request_id": "88600df62ebc0e52-MXP", "message_source": null, "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "1d3156a2-97c1-47f7-9f42-0606512379af", "children": ["be2501e8-538c-4602-8f09-ebb0df8171e7"]}, "be2501e8-538c-4602-8f09-ebb0df8171e7": {"id": "be2501e8-538c-4602-8f09-ebb0df8171e7", "message": {"id": "be2501e8-538c-4602-8f09-ebb0df8171e7", "author": {"role": "tool", "name": "chat_consensus_app__jit_plugin.search_papers", "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1716079439.489303, "update_time": 1716079426.4132562, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Sustainability Practices and Corporate Financial Performance: A Study Based on the Top Global Corporations&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Sustainability is concerned with the impact of present actions on the ecosystems, societies, and environments of the future. Such concerns should be reflected in the strategic planning of sustainable corporations. Strategic intentions of this nature are operationalized through the adoption of a long-term focus and a more inclusive set of responsibilities focusing on ethical practices, employees, environment, and customers. A central hypothesis, that we test in this paper is that companies which attend to this set of responsibilities under the term superior sustainable practices, have higher financial performance compared to those that do not engage in such practices. The target population of this study consists of the top 100 sustainable global companies in 2008 which have been selected from a universe of 3,000 firms from the developed countries and emerging markets. We find significant higher mean sales growth, return on assets, profit before taxation, and cash flows from operations in some activity sectors of the sample companies compared to the control companies over the period of 2006\u20132010. Furthermore, our findings show that the higher financial performance of sustainable companies has increased and been sustained over the sample. Notwithstanding sample limitation, causal evidence reported in this paper suggests that, there is bi-directional relationship between corporate social responsibilities practices and corporate financial performance.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Rashid Ameer&quot;,&quot;Radiah Othman&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2012,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of Business Ethics&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/sustainability-practices-corporate-financial-ameer/76ef1c82609a5a0d8769bfc2e3db0bd5/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1007/s10551-011-1063-y&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;108&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;61-79&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:1},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Improving Corporate Environmental Performance: Encouraging Sustainable Commerce Through Regulatory and Other Governmental Action&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Basic structure of corporations and the relationship between corporations and the environment create powerful reasons for environmental underperformance by firms. Major overhaul to corporations law, environmental law, or both could solve these problems but is unlikely at least within the US. As a result, smaller-scale governmental efforts to induce environmentally-sound corporate behavior presents an attractive possibility for near-term improvements. The recent sustainability efforts of major corporations present hopeful signs that private efforts at sustainable commerce, leveraged through public actions such as procurement, assistance, and partnerships, can achieve further environmental gains more quickly and more economically than traditional command-and-control regulation alone. By sustainable commerce, we mean products and practices that minimize environmental impacts and optimize commercial value while realizing both public and private environmental benchmarks. The term includes means of improving the environment often described as sustainable development, greentech, cleantech, and the like. US corporations still lag behind in the adoption of sustainable commerce compared to their global counterparts, and national and subnational governments have passed over opportunities to encourage its expansion. A system relying on stimulating sustainable commerce and providing incentives for environmentally positive performance - especially one that understands and responds to problems inherent in the traditional structure of the corporation - will achieve faster and better environmental results than a command-and-control program alone. Unique characteristics of environmental threats provide some insights into understanding why these problems resist easy solutions. Environmental threats directly affecting human health are diffuse and often operate at a subclinical level of impact. Obtaining legal redress is therefore difficult. To complicate matters further, even if an individual correctly calculates her potential harm, she may nevertheless rationally choose to free-ride on the efforts of others (either other private actors or the government) for protection against the danger. For these reasons and more, markets do not provide accurate and up-to-date signals to economic actors that induce them to anticipate negative externalities that they should internalize and to protect against them either through such actions as proactive abatement activity or insurance. As important economic actors comprised of multiple stakeholders, corporations face additional difficulties in internalizing externalities and taking proactive steps to prevent against creating environmental problems. Basic corporate structure also creates principal/agent problems arising from unshared goals and asymmetric information that are widely discussed in the literature. These fundamental aspects of the firm predicts that corporations will usually underperform from an environmental standpoint. Although current corporate governance structures allow a corporation to pursue sustainable commerce if management so chooses, reliance on voluntary efforts through a corporate social responsibility model (CSR) will prove insufficient to achieve comprehensive environmental improvement. Some firms will require greater impetus to improve their environmental performance, and others will respond only to command-and-control regulations. When the difficulties of responding to environmental problems encounter the principal/agent problems inherent in the corporation, environmental catastrophe can predictably ensue. As a historical matter, the national government in the US has responded to environmental threats and degradation primarily through comprehensive command-and-control regulations. National regulation emerged as a response to weak regulation from state governments and their inability to address interstate problems. Although federal regulations have resulted in dramatic environmental improvements and recovery, they often meet with resistance by members of the regulated community, which consist primarily of corporations. Corporations commonly complain that the costs imposed by the regulations exceed the benefits gained or harms avoided. Their chief concern is actually that the costs harm their own bottom lines. The US command-and-control regulations of the 1970s and 1980s emerged from an adversarial vision of government relations with private enterprise, one that fundamentally mistrusted the willingness of the private sector to act in an environmentally-protective way even when these actions were ultimately in the long-term best economic interest of both the firm and the nation. That jaded view probably correctly assessed most corporations\u2019 responses to environmental challenges and still captures the attitude of many firms. Despite their efficacy, command-and-control regulations have often come at great cost and fostered resistance to regulation through such tactics as litigation challenging regulations and resort to political processes that undermine the regulatory direction of these programs. Given the current political climate in the US, the likelihood is slim that Congress will adopt a new regulatory scheme for such problems as global climate change (GCC). GCC poses additional difficulties. Greenhouse gases (GHGs) have residence time in the atmosphere that is typically measured in decades, and most of the more significant predicted effects of GCC will occur not immediately but in the mid- to long-term. Stakeholders interested in short-term corporate profits or share value will eschew adopting GHG abatement measures that cut into bottom lines. Informational asymmetry also hampers response. Although general patterns of GCC impacts can be predicted, specific events are harder to link to it, and the effects of GCC will be felt in diffuse areas, often far from the site of the sources of the pollution. To the extent that a global legal solution is required, the lack of effective legal regimes (especially in the near term) renders a true top-down solution nearly impossible. Similarly, a complete overhaul to US corporations law is unlikely. Although some commentators have called for the creation of a new form of corporation, they have not theorized how to require corporations to adopt this form. Voluntary adoption of the sustainable corporation form in the US, like CSR, will likely not produce near term results. Sustainable commerce, especially as achieved through public/private partnerships, presents an underutilized strategy for further environmental gains. Publicly-required adherence to private ordering systems can provide one means of achieving systematic improvement of environmental performance, and public actors can through encouragement and regulation create positive incentive for private actors to adopt these means. Procurement and debarment also offer opportunities to economically pressure environmentally sound performance. Through these private public partnerships, environmental problems can be averted more successfully than through pure regulation alone.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Peter A. Appel&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2011,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;ERN: The Corporate Form (Topic)&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/improving-corporate-performance-encouraging-appel/a192c8ff8f87590ab1f5d32141aa103f/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.2139/ssrn.1924808&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:2},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Self-claimed sustainability: Building social and environmental reputations with words&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Abstract In the attempt of benefiting from positioning themselves as sustainable enterprises, some companies have indiscriminately claimed to operate under sustainable management. At the same time, diverse sustainability indexes have been developed to state the practice, as consumers and general stakeholders seem to value this attitude toward businesses. In that sense, studies have demonstrated the gap between corporate strategic intention and its actual implementation, as well as the use of short-term image building strategies through punctual promotional marketing activities, arguably disconnected of a consistent sustainability strategy. While some companies indeed seek to attain stakeholders\u2019 expectations on sustainable practices, others seem to restrain sustainability merely to their public communication. Within this reasoning some questions emerge: How may corporate social and environmental reputations possibly be built over sustainable and unsustainable operations? What would be the antecedents of corporate reputation allowing for both constructions? In order to offer theoretical bases for the approach of these issues, the present work proposes two theoretical frameworks for the building of \u201ctrue\u201d and \u201cfalse\u201d social and environmental corporate reputations. Ultimately we aim to demonstrate that, based on corporate speech, the construction of sustainable reputations disconnected from real sustainable operations is logically possible.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. Nunes&quot;,&quot;C. L. Park&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2017,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Sustainable Production and Consumption&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/selfclaimed-sustainability-building-reputations-words-nunes/f9bda31998d85f59aca02bbc88134077/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/J.SPC.2016.04.002&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;11&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;46-57&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:3},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Ethical motivations for green business and engineering&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Corporate references to \u201csustainability\u201d and the operative process of \u201cgreen business\u201d have become almost commonplace over the past decade. Companies not only seek to comply with environmental regulations, but many have discovered that techniques for reducing adverse environmental impact often have positive effects on corporate profitability as well. Such adoptions of green business and engineering practices are morally neutral because the driving forces behind them are legal and economic, but not ethical. In some instances, however, managers and engineers have undertaken green business initiatives with the notion of doing something positive for future humans and for the natural environment. In this paper we discuss the \u201cgreen\u201d driving forces behind moral decisions regarding the adoption of green engineering and business practices and conclude that most \u201cgreen engineering\u201d known to the public is simply good business practice. Only when engineering and business begin the \u201cgreen engineering\u201d program with the aim of reducing adverse impact on health or environment does \u201cgreen engineering\u201d become morally admirable.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Jamie R. Hendry&quot;,&quot;P. Vesilind&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2005,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Clean Technologies and Environmental Policy&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/motivations-business-engineering-hendry/959793cba0365e8ca666dc2cb882be46/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1007/S10098-005-0013-8&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;7&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;252-258&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:4},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Public policy and corporate environmental behaviour: a broader view&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Corporate strategies to manage the business\u2013ecological environment interface have evolved against the backdrop of regulatory pressures and stakeholder activism. Despite its relevance with respect to sustainable development, a well developed theory encompassing all aspects of corporate environmental behaviour, especially incorporating incentive compatible public policy measures, is yet to be developed. This paper is a step in this direction, aiming to assimilate contributions related to different aspects of corporate environmental behaviour, capturing the transition from environmental management to environmental strategy. In the process we identify areas where there is a need for further research. We find that there is plenty of scope in developing more complex models to explain a manager&#x27;s rationale for adopting sustainable strategies in the backdrop of the policy regime, and in conducting more empirical (both descriptive and quantitative) work to obtain clearer insights into managerial decisions. Copyright \u00a9 2007 John Wiley &amp; Sons, Ltd and ERP Environment.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;R. Sarkar&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2008,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Corporate Social Responsibility and Environmental Management&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/policy-behaviour-view-sarkar/44175cdb8aef5aac927e191bc6cd6736/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1002/CSR.167&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;15&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;281-297&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:5},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Understanding the Role of the Corporation in Sustainability Transitions&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The state of the planet calls for large-scale sustainability transitions involving systemic adoption of markedly better environmental and social practices. The objective of this symposium is to better understand the role of corporations in promoting such systemic change. We present four case studies\u2014representing diverse industries and change mechanisms\u2014-to investigate corporate leadership in sustainability transitions. The cases examine a wide range of mechanisms used by corporations to progress toward sustainability, such as political coalition building and information strategies through eco-labels, socially responsible investing, and the public statements of CEOs. In this introduction, we discuss the challenges associated with both achieving and studying systemic change, explain the rationale for a case study approach, describe the findings from the case studies, and draw some general conclusions on the mechanisms by which firms may be able to lead, or at least participate in, systemic change in the different phases of sustainability transitions.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. Delmas&quot;,&quot;Thomas P. Lyon&quot;,&quot;J. Maxwell&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2019,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Organization &amp; Environment&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/understanding-role-corporation-sustainability-delmas/8c10460bc73b5355bde07270bd1eb084/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1177/1086026619848255&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;32&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;87 - 97&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:6},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;CSR and environmental responsibility: motives and pressures to adopt green management practices&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;This paper examines the diffusion of environmental management initiatives in business and the motives and pressures reported by senior executives to adopt these practices in one industry. We frame these sustainable practices under the umbrella of corporate social responsibility (CSR) and examine the causal drivers of environmental behavior. This study used a mixed-methods approach and included a survey and 17 in-depth interviews with professional sports team and league executives. Data revealed both strategic and legitimacy motives to adopt environmental management practices. More specifically, the analysis suggested that strategic motives were the primary reason for adopting an environmental CSR focus. Motives to address institutional pressures were also found, although to a lesser extent. The paper discusses the role and relevance environmentally focused CSR plays in professional sport organizations in North America and presents suggestions for future research in this area. Copyright \u00a9 2010 John Wiley &amp; Sons, Ltd and ERP Environment.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Kathy Babiak&quot;,&quot;S. Trendafilova&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2011,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Corporate Social Responsibility and Environmental Management&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/responsibility-motives-pressures-adopt-management-babiak/c334f4d298955e98a08b57c558183d9f/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1002/CSR.229&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;18&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;11-24&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:7},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Organizational Sustainability Practices: A Study of the Firms Listed by the Corporate Sustainability Index&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Organizational sustainability (OS) has been guiding the decision-making process of managers in order to generate competitive advantage. This paper aims to identify the sustainable practices performed by large corporations in the implementation of OS. Reports with actions performed by large organizations and their reach in the three pillars of sustainability\u2014environmental, economic, and social dimensions\u2014are disclosed to their main stakeholders, based on short, medium and long-term sustainable goals. These reports often reflect the progress of OS or the progress made toward them. However, few studies investigate the sustainable practices adopted by firms and their reproducibility. A search was performed in reports selected from the firms listed by the Corporate Sustainability Index (CSI) from 2012\u20132016, belonging to the Brazilian stock market in services sector of the economy and employed the Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) methodology. The results showed the strategic planning involving infrastructure, environment, human resources, product innovation, organizational management and deadline setting acted as the baseline for the implementation of the practices found. The findings will guide the managers\u00b4 decisions in the development of their strategic planning, based on practical and objective results.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;\u00c1lamo Alexandre da Silva Batista&quot;,&quot;A. C. Francisco&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2018,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Sustainability&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/sustainability-practices-study-firms-listed-corporate-batista/e3f9cb33829f5a4591e02ce52b54ee51/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.3390/SU10010226&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;10&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;226&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:8},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Environmental Sustainability Practices for SMEs&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The rate and scale of environmental degradation, through economic activities, has triggered widespread awakening among businesses, governments and civil society. The world over, corporations have responded by adopting sustainability practices and reporting. However, much of these happen within the premises of the corporations. As larger organizations outsource their manufacturing and service operations to small and medium enterprises (SMEs), they effectively shift their environmental burden on their vendors. In most developing countries, poor regulations and weak enforcement of environment laws leave the SMEs on their own, to improve their environmental practices. However, their limited resources and managerial capabilities are often inadequate to undertake sustainability practices. This chapter presents the findings of a research conducted among engineering SMEs in India. It proposes a lifecycle approach towards environmental practices and discusses potential business benefits and value creation from this. The chapter gives a roadmap for green business strategies, which SMEs can implement within their organization.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Gurudas Nulkar&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2019,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Green Business&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/sustainability-practices-smes-nulkar/bd58cde63af7527cb70494c1768d2d4a/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.4018/978-1-5225-2662-9.CH001&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:9},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Community Attempts at Sustainable Development through Corporate Accountability&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Sustainable development serves current needs without compromising the ability to serve future needs. Greenwashing is a strategy that companies adopt to engage in symbolic communications with environmental issues without substantially addressing them in actions. This paper aims to raise awareness of corporate greenwashing, drawing attention to issues that progress the trend of individualized responsibility and consumption, while concealing the social and (eco)systemic issues in the process. By drawing on the case study of winter apparel company Canada Goose, this paper questions whether businesses can \u2018go green\u2019 in good faith, if corporate responsibility and environmental responsibility can ever be reconciled, and if there is considerable need to clarify the intended effects and unintended consequences of corporate greenwashing.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;J. A data envelopment analysis (DEA) approach&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;This study ranks publicly listed corporations based on social and environmental (i.e. sustainable) achievements in relation to financial results, by using a data envelopment analysis (DEA) approach with financial performance indicators (return on assets, return on equity and yearly stock return) as inputs and sustainability scores as outputs. The sustainability scores cover a wide range of sustainable practices and were provided by a specialized screening company. Our calculated DEA indices provide a measure of the commitment of firms towards sustainable practices. The main findings are that many companies are positioned well below best practice in their respective industries. Industry sectors that are less scrutinized by the public (e.g. banking) are found to be less competitive in terms of sustainable practices. The world over, corporations have responded by adopting sustainability practices and reporting. However, much of these happen within the premises of the corporations. As larger organizations outsource their manufacturing and service operations to small and medium enterprises (SMEs), they effectively shift their environmental burden on their vendors. In most developing countries, poor regulations and weak enforcement of environment laws leave the SMEs on their own, to improve their environmental practices. However, their limited resources and managerial capabilities are often inadequate to undertake sustainability practices. This chapter presents the findings of a research conducted among engineering SMEs in India. Collectively referred to as sustainability management tools in this paper, voluntary management approaches range from environmental and social audits, indicators, and management systems, to reporting schemes and stakeholder dialogues. While the adoption of such management tools in SMEs has been increasingly anticipated in the academic literature, the rates of awareness and implementation for these management tools are missing. Furthermore, the connections between awareness and implementation remain under-researched. Using a framework for innovation diffusion, the results from a web-based survey with 176 German SME managers investigate these connections. Rogers&#x27; model is particularly useful to identify managerial and organizational characteristics that might explain why particular SMEs are more likely to adopt sustainability management tools. The present study theorizes about and empirically examines the impacts of corporate green practices on financial performance. Indexes of pollution prevention, green supply management, green product development and ISO 14001 adoption are obtained for each firm in a panel of 3490 publicly-traded companies from 58 countries over 13 years. Results show that internal green practices (pollution prevention and green supply chain management) are the major environmental drivers of financial performance, while external green practices (green product development) play a secondary role in determining financial performance. The adoption of ISO 14001 appears to have a negative impact on financial performance. This study provides empirical support for policy-makers promoting environmental practices that may lead to sustainable economic growth.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Ivan Miroshnychenko&quot;,&quot;R. Today, many companies have accepted their responsibility to do no harm to the environment. In relation to corporate social responsibility (CSR), the business community uses frequently-used terms that are commonly considered to be related to corporate ethics. Findings from this study reveal that companies should have clear environmental guidelines, and most importantly enhanced data governance for greater corporate environmental practice. The objective of this symposium is to better understand the role of corporations in promoting such systemic change. We present four case studies \u2014 representing diverse industries and change mechanisms \u2014 to investigate corporate leadership in sustainability transitions. The cases examine a wide range of mechanisms used by corporations to progress toward sustainability, such as political coalition building and information strategies through eco-labels, socially responsible investing, and the public statements of CEOs. They promote, for example, work\u2013life balance, gender equality, and a harassment-free working environment. At times, however, companies fail to keep their promises by not publicizing truthful reports on these practices, or by overlooking employees\u2019 voices on how these practices are implemented. To partly fix that, we developed a deep-learning framework that scored four fifths of the S&amp;P 500 companies in terms of six ISEs, and a web-based system that engages users in a learning and reflection process about these ISEs. We evaluated the system in two crowdsourced studies with 421 participants, and compared our treemap visualization with a baseline textual representation. including the cited articles:\n\n---\n\nI found your insights on the need to constantly adjust sustainability metrics incredibly compelling. It\u2019s true that as our world evolves, so too must our measures of sustainability. This adaptability is crucial if we are to effectively address emerging issues and integrate lessons from past successes and failures.\n\nHowever, I remain skeptical about how well these evolving metrics can function within a capitalist framework. Capitalism often prioritizes short-term profits over long-term sustainability and social equity. For instance, studies have shown that while corporations may adopt sustainability practices, these are sometimes more about public image than genuine environmental stewardship. This gap between corporate intention and actual implementation is evident, as companies often use short-term marketing strategies rather than consistent sustainable practices [(Nunes &amp; Park, 2017)](https://consensus.app/papers/selfclaimed-sustainability-building-reputations-words-nunes/f9bda31998d85f59aca02bbc88134077/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\nA shift towards more cooperative models of resource allocation could offer a solution. These models emphasize shared benefits and collective well-being, potentially leading to more genuine and impactful sustainability practices. A promising concept in this regard is &quot;regenerative capitalism,&quot; which aims to create systems that are not only sustainable but also restorative and equitable [(Fullerton, 2015)](https://consensus.app/papers/pathways-to-regenerative-capitalism-fullerton/1d52f69a22d2f163b4ed25b04b76359f/?utm_source=chatgpt). This approach emphasizes the interconnectedness of ecological health, social well-being, and economic prosperity, aiming to create a more holistic and just economic system.\n\nGiven your thoughts on sustainability metrics and their need for constant adjustment, I\u2019m curious about your opinion on integrating cooperative models into our current economic system. Do you think these models could coexist effectively with capitalism, or do you foresee significant challenges in their integration?\n\n---\n\nCitations: \n[(Nunes &amp; Park, 2017)](https://consensus.app/papers/selfclaimed-sustainability-building-reputations-words-nunes/f9bda31998d85f59aca02bbc88134077/?utm_source=chatgpt)\n[(Fullerton, 2015)](https://consensus.app/papers/pathways-to-regenerative-capitalism-fullerton/1d52f69a22d2f163b4ed25b04b76359f/?utm_source=chatgpt)\n\nLike our GPT? What might we measure (for example, the human health impacts of production, the living wage for and working conditions of workers)? What might be some creative ways to incorporate and integrate those new types of metrics into sustainability? Is there a technological fix?\n\nThe only constant is change - there is not one solution, there is not one right answer that we can identify, arrive at, and then stop and rest. Whatever metrics we use, one thing we can be sure of is that we need to consistently review the metrics and see if they are the best version of themselves that we can identify using our most current knowledge and experience. \n\nFor example, if we initially set out to track the impact of an eco-resort on the economy of a local village, we may find that the economy has been affected in multiple ways, some of which create ripple effects of their own in increasing materials usage (Mang, 2016). Isolating single elements and tracking them may not be as effective as analyzing the whole while studying metrics on multiple levels. \n\nWith the rise of technological supply chain tracking, there is a possibility that we can provide transparent knowledge of supply chains that will let us make choices about production and use by providing the ability to know how a product is produced (and proof, instead of marketing and good-sounding words). As Mutz points out, this can happen through sensors, tracking, and data science that back up specific sustainability and ethical production claims (Mutz, 2019). \n\nUsing technology to build our ability to verify and trace can provide unbiased information that citizens can use to make more informed decisions. We can have verifiable information about working conditions for people who make products, and verifiable information about the conditions under which fish were caught for consumption, and what pollutants they contain (Mutz, 2019). \n\nIn his Columbia University lecture Steven Cohen mentions how important it is to look out for greenwashing - where an organization that is not actually sustainable finds ways to appear to be sustainable on the surface (Cohen, 2011). So according to\n\n00:31\nOrganization or jurisdictions indicators of resource utilization, waste reduction, and pollutant discharges into the environment. He basically then goes on to kind of discuss the different aspects of sustainability that organizations should focus on and measure in order to kind of get an accurate picture of just how sustainable an organization is.\n\n01:01\nAnd he says that we should focus on four different things. So first one is material intensity, which is basically what element is being thrown away during the production and doesn&#x27;t go into the product itself. And also, does the product have any potential for being reused or recycled in some way?\n\n01:28\nThe next item that he says it should be focused on is energy intensity, which is basically just a measure of the net fuel that is consumed to provide the heat and the power that&#x27;s required for the production process for a certain product, and basically then goes on to discuss the overall efficiency of that fuel and whether it can be recovered and reused in some way, just to make it more sustainable overall.\n\n01:57\nWater consumption is the third item that he says should be focused on. How much of the water... How much water does get used in a production process, basically, and whether or not that water can be reused or if it&#x27;s contaminated and has to go to waste after it&#x27;s used in the production process. And then the next one is toxic emissions.\n\n02:26\nHe basically says it is a degree of toxicity that has to be measured. And basically whether or not we have a way of dealing with it or if it&#x27;s just going to be something that basically goes out into the environment and starts to affect people&#x27;s health negatively and whether or not there&#x27;s anything that we can do in order to prevent that. And I&#x27;m sorry, I think I said there was four items, but there&#x27;s actually five.\n\n02:56\nor emissions from pollutants and basically focusing on the health impacts of those pollutants and whether or not there&#x27;s anything that we can do about them. And also how geography kind of affects the impact of those emissions, meaning like where it&#x27;s coming from, whether or not it&#x27;s affecting nearby residents or people who just reside in the area where the pollutants are being emitted.\n\n03:25\nThe relationship between sustainability and performance measures for an organization. He says that sustainability is an aspect of performance measures because it just kind of helps to determine the overall success of an organization. And then goes on to say that metrics do have to be created and reported separately initially. So basically keeping your sustainability.\n\n03:53\nmeasures separate from your regular performance measures, but then eventually needing to integrate them so that they&#x27;re kind of one in the same rather than keeping them separate. And then that way it basically makes sustainability measures of equal importance as existing performance measures, whether they&#x27;re financial or non-financial.\n\n04:22\nAnd then lastly, it&#x27;s important to measure sustainability in general, according to Cohen, because he says that it measures force precision in defining goals and actions that basically help to achieve those goals. And then goes on to say that these measures will go on to be used to allocate resources more appropriately.\n\n04:50\nSo that way you&#x27;re not allocating resources to things that don&#x27;t necessarily mean it while neglecting others and then just kind of not kind of performing as well as you should be because you&#x27;re not allocating resources correctly. And then he also states that measuring sustainability also helps to improve organizational routine overall.\n\n\n\nPart 2: Because there are no globally agreed upon set of standard sustainability metrics, and considering the complexity of process chains in a global economy, how might those metrics evolve or grow to include other indicators of measurement? What might we measure (for example, the human health impacts of production, the living wage for and working conditions of workers)? What might be some creative ways to incorporate and integrate those new types of metrics into sustainability? Is there a technological fix?\n\nThe only constant is change - there is not one solution, there is not one right answer that we can identify, arrive at, and then stop and rest. Whatever metrics we use, one thing we can be sure of is that we need to consistently review the metrics and see if they are the best version of themselves that we can identify using our most current knowledge and experience. \n\nFor example, if we initially set out to track the impact of an eco-resort on the economy of a local village, we may find that the economy has been affected in multiple ways, some of which create ripple effects of their own in increasing materials usage (Mang, 2016). Isolating single elements and tracking them may not be as effective as analyzing the whole while studying metrics on multiple levels. \n\nWith the rise of technological supply chain tracking, there is a possibility that we can provide transparent knowledge of supply chains that will let us make choices about production and use by providing the ability to know how a product is produced (and proof, instead of marketing and good-sounding words). As Mutz points out, this can happen through sensors, tracking, and data science that back up specific sustainability and ethical production claims (Mutz, 2019). \n\nUsing technology to build our ability to verify and trace can provide unbiased information that citizens can use to make more informed decisions. We can have verifiable information about working conditions for people who make products, and verifiable information about the conditions under which fish were caught for consumption, and what pollutants they contain (Mutz, 2019). \n\nIn his Columbia University lecture Steven Cohen mentions how important it is to look out for greenwashing - where an organization that is not actually sustainable finds ways to appear to be sustainable on the surface (Cohen, 2011). Finding ways to provide verifiable information through technology is an exciting possibility for continuing to make transparent the conditions under which goods are produced, and for incorporating measures of working conditions into our everyday consumption choices. \n\nReferences\n\nColumbia University. (2011, November 1). Steven Cohen, sustainability metrics [Video]. YouTube.\n\nMang, P., Haggard, B., &amp; Regensis Group. (2016). Regenerative development and design: A framework for evolving sustainability. John Wiley &amp; Sons.\n\nMutz, M. (2019, September). How supply chain transparency can help the planet [Video]. Is conversational in tone and adds new info while also asking  simple question which requests the posters opinion or thoughts on a topic\n\nNishay\n\nPart A: How are you preparing your grant narrative? What tools are you using to prepare?\n\n          Preparing a grant narrative involves several steps to ensure that the proposal effectively communicates the project&#x27;s purpose, goals, objectives, and intended impact. To prepare my grant narrative, I&#x27;m first conducting thorough research on the funding organization&#x27;s priorities, requirements, and past grant recipients to tailor my proposal accordingly. Then, I&#x27;m outlining the key components of the narrative, including the executive summary, project description, budget, timeline, and evaluation plan. I&#x27;m also gathering relevant data, statistics, and testimonials to support the need for my project and its potential impact. Another important thing I have been doing to prepare is defining my plan and reviewing all my projected expenses so I can formulate my budget. One thing this has entailed is looking for empty buildings I would want to lease to run my art program from and then calling the realtors of them to discuss pricing and availability. Additionally, I&#x27;m seeking feedback from peers, mentors, and experts in grant writing to refine and strengthen my narrative. I have been talking about my plans like crazy with everyone in my network.\n\n        Tools that I have been using are the: internet, especially google, google docs, excel spreadsheets and project management tools like Trello to keep track of tasks, deadlines, and milestones throughout the grant writing process. Additionally I am using the handy text books for this grant writing course, specifically Effective Planning Strategies and Proposal Writing by Salene Cowher and Larry Dickson, which has many helpful templates and pages to help organize your ideas for your grant. Also, I am looking at funded grant proposals. Lastly I am also calling upon my networks as Carrie Morgridge mentioned as one of her 4 pillars in her Ted talk we watched this week (Morgridge, 2018 [YouTube/Tedtalk]).\n\nPart B: What questions do you have about writing a grant?\n\nBecause the change outcomes of my project are often very positive emotional and social health benefits in the individual participants and more positive identity formation that happens over a span of time, these things can be difficult to measure. I do have some surveys I have conducted on individuals right after doing an event, which will help me some, but it is not enough. I also plan to use research I have gathered that supports the predicted outcomes will be positive change.
