Heah&quot;,&quot;Kenneth Keng Wee Ong&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2015,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/guide-research-projects-engineering-students-planning-leong/017a521bfa48582298241391f26e3cb2/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1201/b18756&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:7},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Essay Planning and Essay Writing&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;ABSTRACT Undergraduate students are commonly advised to make plans of their essays before they begin writing, yet there is little empirical evidence on the nature, role or efficacy of essay planning. This paper examines findings from a recent study of coursework essay\u2010writing as an aspect of student learning in the social sciences. A total of 16 Psychology and 17 History students took part in the investigation, which mainly took the form of two sets of semi\u2010structured interviews. From an analysis of the interview transcripts, five planning strategies were identified. However, it was apparent that to gain a full understanding of the nature of planning, it was necessary to examine these strategies in the light of the main findings of the study\u2014a qualitative analysis of differences in the students\u2019 conceptions of what an essay was and what essay\u2010writing involved. In sum, what seemed important was less how a student planned than what planning was directed towards.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;D. Hounsell&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1984,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Higher Education Research &amp; Development&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/essay-planning-essay-writing-hounsell/d385007c9fa8571a99b3f5db57a18d4b/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/0729436840030102&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;3&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;13-31&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:8},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The Drafts of Strategy: Opening up Plans and their Uses&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;This paper aims to show empirically that strategic plans may contribute to the emergence of new strategies, and not just to programming of predefined strategies. It does so thanks to a novel approach to planning, in which the analyst opens strategic plans, reads their contents, and studies how business actors use them. This method is applied to the analysis of Renault&#x27;s investment strategy in Brazil in the mid-1990s. The author demonstrates that, although the planning process may have acted during this investment as a constraint on innovative strategising, the plans that were produced in order to prepare the investment were open, creative documents. Thanks to their visual and textual representation of contexts and strategies, these plans enhanced strategic imagination more than they hindered the conception of new strategies. The paper argues that all plans may play such a role, depending on how they are written and read. It concludes with recommendations on how to best read and write plans.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. The authors stress that grant writers need to communicate the thrust of the project in a direct and integrated fashion. They assert that clear, understandable language which quickly helps the reader understand the proposal is critical to a successful review, and they offer suggestions for structuring and writing the proposal to enhance comprehension. They recommend conventions for clearly presenting key components such as timelines, work scope, and evaluation plans, and they also offer ideas for designing an evaluation plan that is responsive to project components, has a high potential for effectiveness, and will be simple to operationalize. The budget planning process is analyzed, with examples for developing budget components, displaying and communicating them effectively, and outlining strategies for generating future funding. Finally, the authors provide ideas for communicating the capability of the agency in a way which emphasizes strengths and capacities to implement the project successfully.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Wilfred Wienke&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1996,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Teacher Education and Special Education&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/book-reviews-current-resources-grantwriters-wienke/715106da10e25e01bf8542f795950429/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1177/088840649601900325&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;19&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;272 - 276&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:10},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Successful proposal strategies for small businesses: using knowledge management to win government, private-sector, and international contracts. sixth edition (frey, r.s.) [book reviews]&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The sixth edition of this book provides a valuable guide applicable to businesses small, medium, and large. The book contains 24 content-rich chapters, four appendices of additional resources and tools, a handy list of acronyms and abbreviations, an extensive bibliography for further reading, and a detailed index, as well as a compact disc (CD) full of usable forms and documents described in great depth in the book. Internalization and application of the tools and practices presented in this book should help any US business write successful proposals that win a variety of types of contracts both domestically and internationally. Overall, this book is an exceptional resource for companies of all sizes-not just small ones-looking to create successful proposals. One notable problem with the text is its incredible length. This book is a total of 716 pages of single-spaced text that would take approximately a week of five hours of reading per day for an employee to finish (figuring two minutes per page, plus time to peruse the CD), and it is unlikely the average employee or manager has that kind of time to spare. Another issue is that it does not provide any information for a foreign business looking to do business with the US. Though the general business advice and proposal writing strategies contained therein seem as if they would be equally applicable to an internationally-based company, a separate chapter or at least a section in Chapter 22 on such concerns would make the book more universally appealing and could enable greater international sales of it. Aside from those concerns, however, this book is a highly valuable tool crafted by an experienced professional.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Robert S. Frey&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2013,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;IEEE Transactions on Professional Communication&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/proposal-strategies-businesses-using-knowledge-frey/afbc16d9cab45ac691df0418c12109ef/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1109/TPC.2013.2246358&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;56&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;86-88&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:11},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The writing strategies of graduate research students in the social sciences&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;SummaryA 35-item questionnaire concerning writing habits, experiences of writing and productivity was sent to 228 full-time, U.K. domiciled, social science research students. One hundred and one complete responses were received. Cluster analysis was used to identify three distinct groups of students in terms of the strategies they used when writing: \u201cPlanners\u201d, who planned extensively and then made few revisions, \u201cRevisers\u201d, who developed content and structure through extensive revision, and \u201cMixed Strategy\u201d writers, who both planned before starting to write and revised extensively as part of their writing processes. The Planners reponed higher productivity than both the Revisers and Mixed Strategy Writers. Planners and Revisers did not differ significantly in how difficult they found writing to be; Planners found writing less difficult than did the Mixed Strategy Writers. We conclude that working from a plan can be an effective writing strategy for some, but that planning is neither a necessary nor a sufficient condition for writing success.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. Torrance&quot;,&quot;G. Thomas&quot;,&quot;E. Devoid of case studies and end-of-chapter exercises, the book delivers the following message: here\u2019s the way to take your marketable product and/or service and package it into successful proposals to present to potential clients. Taking readers through the processes of planning, writing, designing, documenting, and presenting the proposal, Bowman and Branchaw are concise, yet readable. The end-of-chapter summaries, which list and enumerate the key points, are particularly helpful to the executive with little time to reread the text in full. The absence of the usual textbook components will no doubt make this guidebook attractive to the realworld practitioner. However, this book could be applicable in several classroom situations. The authors suggest its use in &amp;dquo;report writing ... management or marketing classes&amp;dquo; (p. xi), but I would extend the list to include graduate courses in business writing, any advanced course in sales management, in-house company training programs, and, possibly, adult education. For new academic researchers, adapting to academic writing norms and awareness of expected academic writing standards are likely to help them better prepare for their studies. Roslyn Petelin provides valuable advice and useful strategies for researchers and other writing-reliant workers in her book How Writing Works: A Field Guide to Effective Writing. In the first two chapters of the book, the relationship between reading and writing processes is discussed. On the one hand, it is suggested that conscious, sustained reading of excellent writing helps the novice to absorb ideas about the craft of writing, including word choice, sentence structure, paragraphing, and punctuation. On the other hand, Petelin develops a heuristic for professional writing which includes considerations of the writing\u2019s subject, purpose, readers, and context. She suggests that the adoption of this framework in the early writing process enables writers to consider how to convey their ideas accurately to intended readers from different backgrounds. In the following eight chapters, practical strategies are offered for using elements of grammar, sentence structure, punctuation, and genres in written presentations. For example, Petelin suggests that the use of \u201cstrong\u201d verbs, instead of \u201cheavy\u201d nouns, gives academic writing a direct, dynamic tone. To enhance the quality of written documents, Petelin provides an assessment checklist for academic writing which may be used as a quality-control mechanism. Readers will find concrete advice in this book, to assist them from the conceptual stage of writing to the final proofreading. The strength of this book lies in its being well organised for practical purposes. Each chapter consists of theoretical discussion and practical exercises to enable the application of the theory. For example, in Chapter eleven, which offers guidelines for revising documents, there is a practical exercise to test the reader\u2019s ability to identify and correct common sentence errors. Thus, newly acquired skills can be immediately applied to post-chapter activities, thereby reinforcing the impact of theoretical learning. Overall, this is a systematic general-purpose book. Its potential use is not restricted to educators and researchers, but, for me, as a non-native English speaker and junior researcher, working with Roslyn Petelin\u2019s book helped me to master the standards required of various genres within academic writing. This book is a good starting point for researchers who are exposed to an English writing environment for the first time and is likely to help them to enhance their writing efficacy.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Jie Liu&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2022,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Educational Review&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/writing-works-field-guide-writing-liu/c74195032e805aa4a91943f98d04887c/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/00131911.2022.2147287&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;75&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;1030 - 1030&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:15},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The relationship of participation and effectiveness in strategic planning&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;This paper describes the results of a study focusing on effectiveness and participation in strategic planning and their inter-relationships. The work reported is a comparative study of ten, diverse organizations in the United Kingdom. The paper sets out the frameworks for effectiveness and participation against which the empirical work took place; describes the results of the analysis undertaken; and postulates a number of theories concerning effective planning practice and its relation to participation in the system.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;R. Dyson&quot;,&quot;M. Foster&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1982,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Strategic Management Journal&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/relationship-participation-effectiveness-planning-dyson/90f3c21073ed52a8aed42966f69e6617/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1002/SMJ.4250030107&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;3&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;77-88&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:16},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Lessons Learned About Planning&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The author summarizes the most important lessons he has learned in more than 40 years of studying planning from the perspectives of planning theory, planning methods, and computer applications in planning. He suggests that planner&#x27;s traditional -professional roles, models, and methods often fail to adequately consider alternative futures and unnecessarily restrict meaningful public participation. He proposes that these problems can be overcome, but not easily, by adopting more community-centered -approaches of planning with the public and using simple, easy-to-use, and -understandable models and methods. The author recognizes that following his advice in practice raises many difficult questions that he cannot currently answer. Research support: None.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;R. Klosterman&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2013,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of the American Planning Association&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/lessons-learned-about-planning-klosterman/060cedbfdb0e5b10830068372f695023/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/01944363.2013.882647&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;79&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;161 - 169&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:17},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Effects of planning strategies on writing dynamics and final texts.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Expert writing involves the interaction among three cognitively demanding processes: planning, translating, and revising. To manage the cognitive load brought on by these processes, writers frequently use strategies. Here, we examined the effects of planning strategies on writing dynamics and final texts. Before writing an argumentative text with the triple-task technique, 63 undergraduates were asked either to elaborate an outline with the argumentative structure embedded (structure-based planning condition), to provide a written list of ideas for the text (list-based planning condition), or to do a non-writing-related filler task (no planning condition). Planning showed no effects on the length of the pre-writing pause and cognitive effort, but influenced writing processes occurrences. Compared to participants in the no-planning condition, those in the planning conditions showed a later activation of revising. Moreover, participants in the structure-based condition were mainly focused on translating in the beginning and middle of composition, whereas their peers tended to distribute their attention among all processes. Planning ahead of writing also resulted in texts with longer words, produced at a higher rate. Only the structure-based planning strategy led to an increase in the number of argumentation elements as well as in essays&#x27; persuasiveness and overall quality. There was, however, no indication that these improvements in final texts were associated with changes in the dynamics of writing. Overall, the use of structure-based plans seems to be an effective and efficient way of improving undergraduates&#x27; argumentative writing.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Teresa Limpo&quot;,&quot;Rui Alexandre Alves&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2018,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Acta psychologica&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/effects-planning-strategies-writing-dynamics-texts-limpo/9bc12b4cfde6511aaac1e7a9a393c3cc/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/j.actpsy.2018.06.001&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;188&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          97-109\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:18},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Communication Strategies for Family Planning&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Find the secret to improve the quality of life by reading this communication strategies for family planning. Here are some key strategies and concepts based on the literature:\n\n1. **Importance of Clear Objectives and Outcomes**:\n   - Successful proposals are built around clear, specific, and attainable objectives. Defining clear outcomes helps in aligning the project\u2019s activities and in evaluating its success.\n\n2. **Understanding the Audience**:\n   - Knowing the audience, their interests, and their priorities is crucial. Tailoring the proposal to align with the funding agency\u2019s goals can increase the chances of success.\n\n3. **Comprehensive Literature Review**:\n   - A well-constructed literature review that identifies gaps in existing research or practice establishes the need for the proposed project and positions it within the current knowledge base.\n\n4. **Detailed Project Methodology**:\n   - Clearly describing the methodology and activities planned for the project demonstrates preparedness and the feasibility of the project.\n\n5. **Budget Justification**:\n   - A transparent and justified budget builds trust with funders and shows that the funds will be managed responsibly.\n\n6. **Impact and Evaluation**:\n   - Outlining how the impact of the project will be measured and evaluated shows commitment to achieving and proving results.\n\nIf you need detailed insights from specific studies on any of these aspects, or if you have a particular area of interest within proposal writing or planning strategies, please let me know, and I can provide more focused information or find relevant research papers."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "8848096228a7baa3-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "43da5e90-5785-4508-9b7e-1c4cc04bd9cf", "children": ["cf04936f-1ae5-4020-bbfb-101801cd4956"]}, "cf04936f-1ae5-4020-bbfb-101801cd4956": {"id": "cf04936f-1ae5-4020-bbfb-101801cd4956", "message": {"id": "cf04936f-1ae5-4020-bbfb-101801cd4956", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1715827606.232216, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["The Student Aid Index (SAI), previously known as the Expected Family Contribution (EFC), is a measure used in the United States to determine an applicant&#x27;s eligibility for financial aid for college. The SAI is calculated based on a family\u2019s taxed and untaxed income, assets, and benefits (such as unemployment or Social Security). It also considers the family size and the number of family members who will attend college during the year.\n\nA &quot;good&quot; SAI number is one that is low because it indicates a lower financial capacity to contribute to college expenses, thereby increasing the likelihood of receiving financial aid. An SAI of zero is considered ideal for those seeking maximum aid, as it means that the family has no financial capacity to contribute to college costs, and the student may qualify for the maximum amount of need-based aid.\n\nEach college may have different thresholds for what they consider a qualifying SAI for full aid, based on their financial aid policies and the cost of attendance. Many institutions aim to meet the full demonstrated need of students whose SAI falls below a certain number, which can vary widely from one institution to another.\n\nTo determine specific aid amounts, the SAI is subtracted from the cost of attendance (COA) at a particular school. The resulting figure is the student&#x27;s demonstrated financial need, which schools try to meet through a combination of grants, loans, and work-study programs.\n\nFor specific guidance on financial aid and understanding how your SAI affects your eligibility, it&#x27;s best to consult directly with the financial aid offices of the schools you are interested in attending. They can provide detailed information based on their specific financial aid policies and the aid packages they offer."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

These side effects are not typical and occur less frequently than with more sedating antihistamines, but they can happen, especially at higher doses. Here\u2019s how we can approach this:\n\n1. **Provide the RFP Details**: Share the key details from the Request for Proposal (RFP), including the goals of the grant, eligibility criteria, evaluation criteria, and any specific requirements for the proposal format.\n\n2. **Outline the Project**: Describe the project you are proposing. This should include:\n   - **Project Title**: A concise and descriptive title for your project.\n   - **Project Summary**: A brief overview of the project, including its objectives and expected impact.\n   - **Need Statement**: A description of the problem or need your project addresses.\n   - **Goals and Objectives**: The specific outcomes you aim to achieve.\n   - **Methodology**: How you plan to implement the project, including key activities and timelines.\n   - **Evaluation Plan**: How you will measure the success of the project.\n   - **Budget**: An outline of the project&#x27;s budget, including a justification for each expense.\n   - **Sustainability**: How the project will continue after the grant funding ends.\n   - **Organization Background**: Information about your organization, including its mission, history, and past successes.\n\n3. **Provide Specific Prompts**: Offer prompts or bullet points for each section of the proposal. For example:\n   - For the **Need Statement**, you might provide: &quot;Explain the current problem in the community that our project aims to solve. Include any relevant statistics or data.&quot;\n   - For the **Methodology**, you might provide: &quot;Detail the steps we will take to implement the project, including a timeline and key activities.&quot;\n\n4. **Review and Edit**: After I generate the initial draft, review it carefully to ensure it aligns with your vision and the RFP requirements. Make any necessary edits or additions.\n\nIf you provide these details, I can generate a comprehensive draft of your grant proposal. Here\u2019s an example of how you might start:\n\n---\n\n### Project Title: [Your Project Title]\n\n### Project Summary\n[Provide a brief overview of your project here. For example, &quot;Our project aims to improve literacy rates among underprivileged children in the community by implementing a comprehensive after-school tutoring program.&quot;]\n\n### Need Statement\n[Describe the problem or need your project addresses. For example, &quot;Currently, 30% of children in our community are reading below grade level. This project seeks to address this issue by providing targeted tutoring and literacy resources.&quot;]\n\n### Goals and Objectives\n[List the specific outcomes you aim to achieve. For example, &quot;By the end of the project, 80% of participating students will improve their reading skills by at least one grade level.&quot;]\n\n### Methodology\n[Detail how you plan to implement the project. For example, &quot;The project will consist of weekly tutoring sessions, each lasting one hour. We will recruit qualified tutors and provide them with training and resources. The project will run from September to June, aligning with the school year.&quot;]\n\n### Evaluation Plan\n[Explain how you will measure the success of the project. For example, &quot;We will assess students&#x27; reading levels at the beginning and end of the project using standardized tests. We will also collect feedback from students, parents, and tutors.&quot;]\n\n### Budget\n[Provide an outline of the project&#x27;s budget. For example, &quot;The total budget for the project is $50,000, which will cover tutor salaries, training materials, and program supplies.&quot;]\n\n### Sustainability\n[Describe how the project will continue after the grant funding ends. For example, &quot;We plan to seek additional funding from local businesses and foundations to sustain the program beyond the initial grant period.&quot;]\n\n### Organization Background\n[Provide information about your organization. Here are a few reasons why you might feel this way, along with some thoughts on how to approach the situation ethically:\n\n1. **Personal Integrity**: You might feel that using AI to write your proposal conflicts with your personal standards of honesty and hard work. Writing a grant proposal is typically seen as a task that reflects your skills, knowledge, and dedication to your project.\n\n2. **Fairness**: There might be concerns about fairness if you feel that using AI gives you an unfair advantage over others who are writing their proposals manually.\n\n3. **Value of Effort**: The effort put into writing a proposal can be a learning experience, helping you better understand your project and its goals. Relying too much on AI might deprive you of this valuable opportunity.\n\n### Ethical Considerations\n\nTo address these concerns and use AI ethically, consider the following:\n\n1. **Collaboration with AI**: View GPT as a collaborative tool rather than a replacement for your effort. Use it to generate drafts, brainstorm ideas, or refine your writing, but ensure the final proposal reflects your understanding and commitment to the project.\n\n2. **Transparency**: Be transparent with your team or stakeholders about how you used AI in the writing process. This can help maintain trust and ensure everyone is on the same page.\n\n3. **Skill Development**: Use the AI-generated content as a learning tool. Analyze the structure, language, and style, and use this knowledge to improve your own writing skills.\n\n4. **Customization**: Make sure the final proposal is tailored to your project and the RFP requirements. Add personal insights, experiences, and specific details that only you can provide.\n\n### Practical Steps\n\nHere\u2019s how you can practically and ethically use GPT to help with your grant proposal:\n\n1. **Initial Draft**: Use GPT to create an initial draft based on the information and guidelines you provide.\n   \n2. **Review and Edit**: Carefully review the draft, making necessary edits to ensure it accurately represents your project and meets the RFP criteria.\n\n3. **Add Personal Touch**: Infuse the proposal with your unique insights, experiences, and passion for the project.\n\n4. **Seek Feedback**: Share the draft with colleagues or mentors for feedback and make further revisions as needed.\n\n5. **Final Polishing**: Ensure the final document is polished, coherent, and aligns with your vision and the funder\u2019s requirements.\n\nBy following these steps, you can leverage the strengths of AI while maintaining the integrity and authenticity of your grant proposal."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

Here are some points to consider that might help you reconcile these feelings:\n\n### Evolution of Writing Tools\n\n1. **Technological Continuum**: The use of AI like GPT is a natural progression in the evolution of writing tools. Just as spell checkers and grammar tools (e.g., Grammarly) help improve the technical quality of your writing, AI can assist in generating content, structuring arguments, and refining language. The key difference is the level of sophistication and capability.\n\n2. **Efficiency and Productivity**: These tools, including AI, are designed to enhance efficiency and productivity. They help writers focus on the substance of their content rather than getting bogged down by mechanics and technical details. This is especially valuable in time-sensitive tasks like grant writing.\n\n### Ethical Use and Personal Effort\n\n1. **Collaboration with AI**: Using AI doesn&#x27;t negate your role in the writing process. You provide the core ideas, direction, and final approval. Think of AI as a collaborator that helps you articulate your thoughts more effectively and efficiently.\n\n2. **Added Value**: Your unique insights, experiences, and knowledge are irreplaceable. AI can help draft and refine, but it cannot replace the personal touch and specific understanding you bring to your proposal. The quality of the input you provide to the AI significantly influences the output.\n\n3. **Ethical Use**: Being transparent about your use of AI and ensuring that the final work reflects your true intentions and understanding can mitigate ethical concerns. You are still the author, directing the content and making critical decisions.\n\n### Perspective on Tools\n\n1. **Normalizing AI Use**: As AI tools become more common, their use in writing and other tasks will likely be normalized, much like other digital tools. The perception that AI-generated content is less valid will change as more people recognize the value and legitimacy of these tools.\n\n2. **Skill Enhancement**: Just as using grammar tools can improve your writing skills over time, using AI can help you learn to structure and articulate your ideas better. This, in turn, enhances your overall skill set.\n\n### Analogies with Other Tools\n\nConsider how calculators revolutionized mathematics. Initially, there might have been concerns about reliance on calculators, but now they are seen as essential tools that allow people to focus on higher-level problem-solving rather than basic arithmetic.\n\nSimilarly, AI in writing should be seen as a tool that allows you to focus on higher-level aspects of your work, such as creativity, strategy, and impact, rather than just the mechanics of writing.\n\n### Final Thoughts\n\nUsing AI to assist in writing your grant proposal is a legitimate and valuable approach, provided you maintain control over the content and ensure it accurately represents your ideas and goals. Embrace AI as a tool that complements your skills and enhances your ability to communicate effectively."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

&quot;Effective Planning Strategies and Proposal Writing: A Workbook for Helping Professionals&quot; by Cowher and Dickson.\n\n### Chapter 3: Needs Assessment\n**Summary**: This chapter focuses on the importance of conducting a needs assessment to identify and prioritize the needs of the target population before planning a project or writing a proposal.\n\n**Key Ideas**:\n1. **Definition and Purpose**: Needs assessment is a systematic process to determine and address gaps between current conditions and desired conditions.\n2. **Methods**: Various methods such as surveys, interviews, focus groups, and existing data analysis.\n3. **Data Collection**: Emphasis on qualitative and quantitative data to provide a comprehensive view.\n4. **Prioritizing Needs**: Techniques for ranking and prioritizing needs based on urgency, feasibility, and impact.\n5. **Stakeholder Involvement**: Importance of engaging stakeholders in the process to ensure relevance and buy-in.\n\n### Chapter 4: Program Planning\n**Summary**: This chapter outlines the steps for effective program planning, from defining goals and objectives to developing strategies and action plans.\n\n**Key Ideas**:\n1. **Goal Setting**: Establishing clear, measurable, and achievable goals aligned with the identified needs.\n2. **Objectives**: Crafting specific, measurable, attainable, relevant, and time-bound (SMART) objectives.\n3. **Strategy Development**: Formulating strategies to achieve the objectives, including identifying resources and activities.\n4. **Action Plan**: Creating detailed action plans that outline tasks, timelines, responsibilities, and resources.\n5. **Evaluation Plan**: Incorporating methods for evaluating the program\u2019s effectiveness and making necessary adjustments.\n\n### Chapter 7: Budgeting and Resource Development\n**Summary**: This chapter covers the principles of budgeting and securing resources necessary for program implementation.\n\n**Key Ideas**:\n1. **Budget Components**: Understanding direct and indirect costs, and the difference between fixed and variable expenses.\n2. **Budget Justification**: Explaining the necessity and reasonableness of each budget item.\n3. **Resource Development**: Identifying potential funding sources, including grants, donations, and partnerships.\n4. **Fundraising Strategies**: Techniques for fundraising, such as grant writing, donor cultivation, and special events.\n5. **Financial Management**: Best practices for managing funds, including accounting, reporting, and compliance.\n\nIf you need more detailed information or specific points from each chapter, feel free to ask!"]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "884725ecfefd3760-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "ae8d3fd9-fc47-4d60-9ce5-01d795386d21", "children": ["ba29c5c8-4c39-4042-898d-08fdfe5668fb"]}, "ba29c5c8-4c39-4042-898d-08fdfe5668fb": {"id": "ba29c5c8-4c39-4042-898d-08fdfe5668fb", "message": {"id": "ba29c5c8-4c39-4042-898d-08fdfe5668fb", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1715818269.448973, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["### Chapter 7, Item 1: Budget Components\n\n**Direct Costs**: Expenses directly tied to the project. These include:\n- **Personnel**: Salaries and wages for staff working on the project.\n- **Fringe Benefits**: Health insurance, retirement plans, and other employee benefits.\n- **Supplies**: Consumables like paper, pens, and materials specific to the project.\n- **Equipment**: Tangible items costing more than a predetermined amount and having a useful life of more than one year.\n\n**Indirect Costs**: General operating expenses not directly linked to the project but necessary for its support. These include:\n- **Administrative Costs**: Office rent, utilities, administrative staff salaries.\n- **Overhead**: Costs incurred for common objectives, such as maintenance, security, and IT services.\n\n**Fixed Costs**: Expenses that remain constant regardless of the project&#x27;s scale. Examples include:\n- **Rent**: Monthly lease payments for office space.\n- **Salaries**: Fixed salaries for full-time employees.\n\n**Variable Costs**: Expenses that fluctuate based on project activities and scope. Examples include:\n- **Supplies**: Costs that vary depending on the amount used.\n- **Travel**: Expenses that change based on the number and distance of trips.\n\n### Additional Considerations:\n- **Contingency Funds**: Allocation for unexpected expenses.\n- **In-Kind Contributions**: Non-monetary resources like volunteer time or donated goods.\n\nUnderstanding these components is crucial for creating a comprehensive and realistic budget that justifies funding needs and ensures the project&#x27;s financial viability."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

Let&#x27;s take another look at Chapter 7, Item 1 from &quot;Effective Planning Strategies and Proposal Writing&quot; by Cowher and Dickson, and provide a more accurate explanation of budget components.\n\n### Chapter 7, Item 1: Budget Components\n\n**Direct Costs**: These are costs that can be directly attributed to the project. They include:\n\n- **Personnel**: Salaries and wages for the project staff.\n- **Fringe Benefits**: Benefits for the project staff, such as health insurance and retirement plans.\n- **Travel**: Expenses for project-related travel.\n- **Supplies**: Materials and supplies necessary for the project.\n- **Equipment**: Any equipment purchases needed for the project.\n- **Consultants/Contractual**: Fees for consultants or contractors hired for specific project tasks.\n- **Other Direct Costs**: Miscellaneous costs directly related to the project, such as printing, training, and communication.\n\n**Indirect Costs**: These are costs that cannot be directly attributed to the project but are necessary for the general operation of the organization. They include:\n\n- **Administrative Expenses**: Costs for general administrative support.\n- **Facilities**: Costs related to the use of office space, utilities, and maintenance.\n- **Overhead**: General operating costs, such as insurance and accounting services.\n\n### Additional Key Points:\n\n- **Budget Justification**: A detailed explanation of why each cost is necessary for the project.\n- **Cost Allocation**: Proper allocation of costs to ensure they are reasonable and necessary for the project.\n- **Monitoring and Reporting**: Regular tracking of expenditures to ensure they align with the budget and comply with funding requirements.\n\nBy accurately defining and justifying both direct and indirect costs, you ensure a comprehensive and credible budget that supports the project\u2019s goals and funding requirements."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

Here\u2019s a guide to help you get started:\n\n### 1. **Identify Your Needs and Eligibility**\n   - Determine the specific purpose for which you need the grant (e.g., education, business startup, research, personal emergency).\n   - Research grants that fit your needs and check if you meet the eligibility criteria.\n\n### 2. **Research Grant Opportunities**\n   - **Government Grants**: Visit websites like Grants.gov in the U.S., which lists available federal grants.\n   - **Non-Profit Organizations**: Look for foundations or non-profits that offer personal grants. Websites like Foundation Center (now Candid) provide databases of grants.\n   - **Local Government and Community Organizations**: Check with local government offices or community centers for available grants.\n\n### 3. **Prepare Your Application**\n   - **Gather Documentation**: Collect necessary documents such as identification, financial statements, and proof of eligibility.\n   - **Write a Proposal**: Clearly state your need, how the grant will be used, and why you are a deserving candidate. Include a budget if necessary.\n   - **Follow Instructions**: Ensure you follow the application guidelines precisely, including format, deadlines, and required attachments.\n\n### 4. **Submit the Application**\n   - Submit your application through the specified method (online, mail, or in-person).\n   - Keep copies of all submitted materials for your records.\n\n### 5. **Follow Up**\n   - After submission, monitor the status of your application.\n   - Be prepared to provide additional information if requested by the grantor.\n\n### 6. **Other Tips**\n   - **Networking**: Connect with people who have received grants or are involved in grant-giving organizations for advice and tips.\n   - **Persistence**: Applying for grants can be competitive, so don\u2019t get discouraged if you don\u2019t receive one on your first try. However, GPT-4 itself does not inherently have the capability to speak.\n\nThat said, GPT-4 can be integrated with text-to-speech (TTS) systems to provide spoken responses. This is often done by developers who use GPT-4 as the backend for generating text, which is then converted to speech using a TTS engine. 5\n\n\nPart A: Describe the difference between a program&#x27;s purpose, goal, and objective. Explain why each is important when competing for a grant.\n\n\n\n\nIn program development, particularly in grant applications, it is essential to differentiate between the program&#x27;s purpose, goals, and objectives. These elements play a crucial role in presenting a well-constructed proposal to prospective funders. Therefore, it is imperative to have a clear understanding of these components and their significance in the context of program development.\n\n\n\n\nPurpose: A program&#x27;s purpose provides the foundational framework that sets the overall direction. It defines the broad aim of the program and answers why it exists. The purpose is essential in grant writing as it communicates the program&#x27;s core essence and justification to funders, helping them understand the overarching intent behind the initiative (Godwin et al., 1998).\n\n\n\n\nGoals: Goals are broad, general statements that articulate the desired outcomes the program aims to achieve in the long run. They map out the future and provide a measure of success. Goals are essential in grants because they demonstrate the strategic endpoints of the program, giving funders a clear picture of the intended impact and aligning with their interests and priorities (Godwin et al., 1998; Wilburn &amp; Wilburn, n.d.).\n\n\n\n\nObjectives: Objectives are specific, measurable steps that outline how the goals will be achieved. They are concise and detailed, often including specific targets and timelines. Objectives are crucial in grant proposals because they provide measurable benchmarks for evaluating the program&#x27;s success and accountability, ensuring that there are concrete criteria against which the program&#x27;s effectiveness can be assessed (Godwin et al., 1998).\n\n\n\n\nPart B: You are competing for a CLU Social Impact Innovation Fund grant. Your grant is to be compelling enough to earn an award. In one paragraph, describe the grant idea that you will use throughout the class.\n\nWith the goal of improving the overall well-being of society, I propose the creation of the &quot;Global Happiness Initiative Foundation&quot; (GHIF). The foundation is dedicated to improving the quality of life for individuals across the globe through increased access to education, healthcare, travel opportunities, and mental health resources (Backer &amp; Weiler, 2018; Gilbert &amp; Abdullah, 2004; Gray et al., 2019; Ross &amp; Wu, 1995). GHIF is committed to promoting long-term happiness and well-being, free from the limitations of health conditions. This initiative operates as a community and global cooperative effort, with an emphasis on inclusivity and universal benefit. By forging strategic partnerships and implementing innovative service delivery, GHIF aims to make a significant impact by transforming lives and fostering a more connected and joyful world.\n\n\n\n\nPart C: Define your program/idea with the following three details: purpose, goals, and objectives.\n\n\n\n\nPurpose: The purpose of the Global Happiness Initiative Foundation is to enhance the overall well-being and happiness of individuals globally by providing unrestricted access to essential life-enhancing services such as education, healthcare, and mental wellness resources.\n\n\n\n\nGoals:\u00a0\n\u00a0Long-term Goal: To significantly increase the global population&#x27;s access to key well-being services, thereby improving quality of life and happiness.\nShort-term Goal: Establish and strengthen partnerships with local and international organizations to facilitate service delivery and reach a wider audience.\n\n\n\n\nObjectives:\n\u00a0Objective 1: By the end of the first year, launch educational programs in at least three countries, benefiting over 10,000 individuals.\nObjective 2: Within the first six months, partner with at least five major healthcare providers to offer comprehensive health services with an emphasis on preventive care and mental health.\nObjective 3: Develop and implement a scalable model for wellness travel that can be replicated across different regions. The model will be evaluated based on participant satisfaction and repeat engagement rates.\n\n-----------------------------------------------------\n\n\nBacker, E., &amp; Weiler, B. (2018). Travel and quality of life: Where do socio-economically disadvantaged individuals fit in? Journal of Vacation Marketing, 24(2), 159\u2013171.\n\nGilbert, D., &amp; Abdullah, J. (2004). Explain why each is important when competing for a grant.\n\nWhen looking at purpose, goal and objective the purpose is why you are doing what you are doing, the goal is what you are trying to achieve and the objectives are how you are going to achieve your goal. In our reading it says, \u201cObjectives are the building blocks or steps towards achieving a program&#x27;s goals. Objectives are specific and concise statements that state who will make what change, by how much, where and by when\u201d (Wilburn). It is important to have all three because if someone is going to invest into your organization or give you money to make a difference they want to know the basic questions of when, where, what, who, why, and how. When you state your organization&#x27;s purpose, goals and objectives you answer these questions and these investors will be able to see and know where their money is going. \n\nPart B: You are competing for a CLU Social Impact Innovation Fund grant. Your grant is to be compelling enough to earn an award. In one paragraph, describe the grant idea that you will use throughout the class.\n\nHave you ever felt lost, scared, misunderstood, alone, or not enough? Millions of teens feel this everyday and they have no one or no where to turn to. Our organization&#x27;s goal is to create a safe environment and experience for teens to learn many important life skills and coping mechanisms so that they can reach their full potential in life. We will achieve this goal by creating a program where teens can go for 6 months to 2 years and travel the world while doing different humanitarian projects in many different countries. While they help many different people in lots of amazing places, they will learn many new skills that will give them the confidence they need to achieve their goals and dreams in life. This will be a safe place for teens to learn because they will not be forced to do anything and they will feel loved and accepted. All we ask of you is to grant us $500,000 as our starting cost to make this organization a reality. With your help we can turn these feelings of confusion, fear and discouragement into hope, encouragement and joy. \n\nPart C: Define your program/idea with the following three details: purpose, goals, and objectives.\n\nPurpose: Have a safe place where teens can learn different skills to reach their full potential and achieve their life goals and dreams. \n\nGoal: Have a program where teens can go for 6 months to 2 years and travel to different countries while doing different humanitarian projects in each country. Teach many different life skills and coping mechanisms such as communication, confidence, processing feelings and thoughts, and many more. \n\nObjectives: \n\nCreate the program: (hire staff, find different countries and humanitarian projects, receive finances, market program, accept teens, have teens travel and help people, figure out how to duplicate).  \nTalk with teens to figure out their needs. \nFigure out how to meet their needs\n \n\nResources \n\nWilburn, S., &amp; Wilburn, K. T. (n.d.). Developing measurable program goals and objectives. "g-bo0FiWLY7", "request_id": "882744189d8d83a8-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "c7634060-927e-4ba5-8a24-75854123c97c", "children": ["1491b060-9a55-40c6-a3f6-f4892f9edaa8"]}, "1491b060-9a55-40c6-a3f6-f4892f9edaa8": {"id": "1491b060-9a55-40c6-a3f6-f4892f9edaa8", "message": {"id": "1491b060-9a55-40c6-a3f6-f4892f9edaa8", "author": {"role": "tool", "name": "chat_consensus_app__jit_plugin.search_papers", "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1715483974.203847, "update_time": 1715483955.333142, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;99 Grant Writing Program to Enhance Junior Faculty Research Funding Success&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;OBJECTIVES/GOALS: The grant writing process provides investigators with critical thinking, problem solving, and communication skills, crucial for personal and professional development. However, opportunities for junior faculty to learn these skills are highly variable. Thus, we developed a grant writing program to assist in the preparation of an NIH R proposal. METHODS/STUDY POPULATION: The R Club Grant Program was implemented in 2021 for junior faculty of the University of Cincinnati\u2019s College of Medicine and Center for Clinical &amp; Translational Science &amp; Training (CCTST). The program consists of a series of workshops (e.g., How to Craft a Specific Aims Page, How to Construct a Competitive R01 Proposal) utilizing examples of successful proposals and grant review criteria to demonstrate how to translate a conceptual framework into a research proposal (level 1). All participants can receive constructive feedback on a Specific Aims page from an experienced grant writer (level 2), and for a select cohort, the program provides comprehensive scientific content edits and iterative feedback on a full research proposal, with a focus on grantsmanship, presentation, and overall competitiveness (level 3). RESULTS/ANTICIPATED RESULTS: Over three NIH grant cycles, the program to date has provided 38 early-career investigators with multi-level grant writing support. All participants attended the workshops and received supporting documents, 21 received feedback on a Specific Aims page, and 6 received one-on-one writing assistance on their full research proposal. Of the 6 investigators who received the greatest level of support, 3 have received NIH scientific review, with a 66.6% funding success rate for either an original (R01, n=1) or subsequent overlapping (R35, n=1) proposal. In a survey sent to workshop attendees, 100% of respondents (n=23) reported ( Strongly Agreed or Agreed ) that the training was a worthwhile investment in their professional development and 96% stated that they will be able to apply the knowledge and skills learned. DISCUSSION/SIGNIFICANCE: Initial evaluation measures suggest that grant writing support programs have great potential to enhance funding success rates. As the program evolves it will be crucial to evaluate both qualitative and quantitative feedback measures to ensure efforts are directed to the appropriate level(s) of service to maximize the funding success of our faculty.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Jennifer Veevers&quot;,&quot;Patrick H. Ryan&quot;,&quot;Jacqueline M. Knapke&quot;,&quot;J. Blackard&quot;,&quot;S. Schuckman&quot;,&quot;B. Kissela&quot;,&quot;M. Cushion&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2023,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of Clinical and Translational Science&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/writing-program-enhance-junior-faculty-research-funding-veevers/1bacde00ad9d5f44947dad1eeb478a3c/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1017/cts.2023.182&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;7&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;28 - 28&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:1},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Grant Writing as a Funding Source and Collaborative Endeavor.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Grant writing provides not only financial rewards but also insights into the living mission of an institution, and points toward collaborative opportunities within and among various units across a campus. In the future, more and more grant funded programs will be a necessary part of our work in student affairs. This manuscript offers basic tools for understanding best practices of grant writing and the principles that should guide student affairs personnel in grant writing endeavors. Financial constraints throughout academe create heightened attention on external sources of funds. While typically associated with faculty and research, grant writing represents a substantive way in which student affairs personnel can demonstrate their abilities as educators. In terms of professional development, student affairs staff members can benefit from collaboration in writing grants, managing the grants, and in conducting research associated with the project. Their insights to the cocurricular lives of students are a salient perspective that other segments of a campus can benefit from as the dialogue unfolds regarding a grant proposal. The nature of requests for proposals (RFPs) has changed in ways that encourage student affairs to participate actively. For example, many agencies now approach programmatic project ideas from a collaborative viewpoint of the campus, as opposed to non-collaborative, isolated projects. In addition, the evaluation and research components now required in many RFPs necessitate a perspective on the students&#x27; holistic experiences, rather than data such as grade point average or retention rates. The agencies are equally concerned with questions of \\&quot;how\\&quot; and \\&quot;why,\\&quot; as they are with questions of \\&quot;what\\&quot; and \\&quot;how much.\\&quot; Even if student affairs professionals do not take the lead on a grant project, their collaboration with other campus components will become more vital to ensure that co-curricular concerns are addressed. Currently, a dearth of literature exists regarding the involvement of student affairs professionals involved in grant writing endeavors. Guiding Principles Begin with an Idea To receive funding, a proposal must demonstrate fit between the institutional strategic plan, the goals of the sponsor, and the objectives of the project. The strongest proposals demonstrate a rigorous alignment with guidelines of the sponsor. Even an idea with a great deal of merit and research will not be funded if the program goals do not align with those of the sponsor. A writing team should critically examine sponsors that possibly align with a project idea and institution. Many sponsors will post past awardees, including institution, name of project, and contact information. Identify Sponsors Funding sources for grants include federal (e.g., U.S. Department of Education at www.ed.gov) and state agencies (e.g., State Department of Human Services), private foundations (e.g., John and Catherine T. McArthur Foundation at www.macfdn.org, Coca-Cola\u00ae at www2.coca-cola.com/foundation), and professional organizations (e.g., SACSA at www.sacsa.org). Campuses may also be members of national search agencies that will research sponsors for a particular idea or niche. When the proposal is ready to be submitted, the team may choose to submit it to one agency or to more than one. If the proposal is accepted by more than one agency, the campus must choose one and decline the other. Write with a Team Once a project has been generally defined and possible sponsors have been identified, a writing team should be established that is representative of the project stakeholders. The team leader may be pre-determined or designated by the group. For an effective writing team, the project requires personnel familiar with the institutions or departments involved and who also have authority to commit resources on behalf of their units. Once the team is assembled, the members must read through the RFP carefully to identify the requisite components of the proposal. \u2026&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Bonnie V. Daniel&quot;,&quot;J. K. West&quot;,&quot;George E. Daniel&quot;,&quot;P. Flowers&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2006,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;The College Student Affairs Journal&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/grant-writing-funding-source-collaborative-endeavor-daniel/35db8dd735de559fb2d7d7273d0536fb/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;25&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;199-208&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:2},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;An algorithmic approach to an impactful specific aims page.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The most vital part of a grant is the specific-aims section. As the leading section of the proposal, the specific-aims section serves as a 1-page synopsis that needs to gain the attention and interest of the reviewers. It must present a compelling case for the importance of the proposed work and provide a convincing rationale and evidence that you and your team are the best people to carry out the project. Developing the specific-aims page is usually the first stage of the grant writing process, as it provides an overview of the proposal and research directions. Furthermore, it can be instrumental in getting external feedback from program officers, collaborators, and others as the grant develops. The process of writing the Specific Aims page requires that one touch on each of the elements that comprise the scoring criteria of the proposal (eg, significance, innovation, investigator(s), approach, and environment) and succinctly introduce all the main topics that will be addressed in the application, but focus especially on the knowledge gap and the importance of filling it, the central hypothesis and the aims that will address it, and the overall impact of the work. This page sets a clear framework for writing the rest of the grant. In this article, we present a set of recommendations and guidelines on how to utilize an algorithmic approach to develop the specific-aims page, what elements to include, and how to maximize its value to create a competitive grant.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;A. Goldstein&quot;,&quot;S. Balaji&quot;,&quot;A. Ghaferi&quot;,&quot;A. Gosain&quot;,&quot;M. Maggard-gibbons&quot;,&quot;B. Zuckerbraun&quot;,&quot;S. Keswani&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2020,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Surgery&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/approach-aims-page-goldstein/6fa7925b45b15470be9af8ff555bbc5c/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/j.surg.2020.06.014&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:3},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Writing a successful grant application.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;In summary, the research application must focus on a solid objective and be supported by a clear and concise plan for its accomplishment. For the new faculty member applying the first time for outside research funding, it is important to seek help from experienced and more senior colleagues, especially those who are actively serving on NIH Study Sections. It is a good idea to remember that the individuals reviewing applications are some of our busiest scientists. The job of grant review is clearly an added assignment that they willingly donate their time to and one needs to consider this when writing a grant application. Anything that can be done to make the reviewer&#x27;s job easier can only help the application. Brevity, clarity, and organization are essential to a good application. As has been repeatedly mentioned, one of the major application weaknesses sited is a lack of focus, especially in the presentation of the Research Plans. For the new applicant, it is very helpful to plan enough time for completion of the application so that it could be reviewed by others thoroughly knowledgeable in this particular area. Once the application is submitted, the applicant should take advantage of opportunities to interact with the Executive Secretary of the Study Section to which the grant is assigned. Every institution&#x27;s research office maintains a book identifying all of the Study Sections, the current members of the Study Section, and the Chairman. The assignment of the grant application to a particular study is an administrative one occurring at NIH upon receipt of the grant.(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 250 WORDS)&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;J. Niederhuber&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1985,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;The Journal of surgical research&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/writing-grant-application-niederhuber/0127a6f9aab45f98955ae964712f61dd/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/0022-4804(85)90103-9&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;39 4&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          277-84\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:4},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Grant Writing 101&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Abstract Writing a grant is a hefty undertaking. Start by surrounding yourself with a successful mentor and accompanying team with a good track record. Get organized, select clear goals and objectives to your project. Once the foundation for the grant is set, begin by generating a robust hypothesis. Once your hypothesis is clearly defined, you should contact the project officer of the specific grant for which you are applying; they can help identify if the proposal meets an area of need. The basic components of a grant include the following: the face page, which highlights the key contributors; followed by table of contents; abstract; biographical sketches, which are minicurriculum vitae; budget; research plan, which is composed mostly of background, significance, and specific aims; and lastly, references cited. Be sure to follow specific formatting. Use resources including the internet to find an appropriate grant. Finally, given the confines of a busy surgical practice and the significant amount of work necessary to complete a grant, it is essential that the work begins early and well in advance of the proposed deadline.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Jason T. Wiseman&quot;,&quot;K. Alavi&quot;,&quot;Robert J Milner&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2013,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Clinics in Colon and Rectal Surgery&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/grant-writing-wiseman/9486447a0b3058e58f1a8f380dc7ab3a/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1055/s-0033-1356722&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;26&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;228 - 231&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:5},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Grant Writing: The Uncertain Road to Funding&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Grant writing is not a mysterious process. It is based on sound planning, development, implementation and evaluation strategies. An important component of the grant/proposal writing process is to address not only the needs of the organization, but also the needs of the funding source. The opportunity to capture your intended funder&#x27;s attention is limited, usually to the first few sentences. Make the most of the opportunity by concentrating on the opening sentences of the proposal. Make no mistake -fewer words make a great impact.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;C. Zagury&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1995,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Complementary Health Practice Review&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/grant-writing-uncertain-road-funding-zagury/dfd2ef57b3745112bb9ba9309863aaea/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1177/153321019500100214&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;1&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;139 - 143&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:6},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The art of grant writing&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;How many scientists, while writing a grant proposal, realize that they are producing a marketing document? The answer is, not enough, but the ones who do understand that they are selling their ideas and skills to the grant reviewers are the well-funded ones. The ability to market your ideas is the most critical feature of the art of grant writing.Marketing your research plan of course requires that you have a good idea, one that is creative, innovative, exciting and do-able. In clinical medicine or engineering, ideas might also be judged on their potential to lead to a pragmatic application. And, from the grant giver&#x27;s standpoint, a good idea has another important attribute. The grant giver&#x27;s goal is to fund work that furthers their mission. A good idea is one that&#x27;s in line with that mission. It came as a surprise to me several years ago when I realized that the main aim of the National Institutes of Health or the Medical Research Council is to not fund my research. Thus, the most important homework you can do, before writing the first word of a grant application, is to match your priorities with those of one or more grant givers.One of the most important things you can do to ensure that your writing is clear and focused is to get experienced grant writers to review drafts of your proposal. These should include an expert in your field, a good scientific editor (especially important if you&#x27;re writing in a language other than your mother tongue) and an intelligent non-specialist. A grant-savvy scientist in another discipline is best qualified to catch fuzzy writing and jargon. Finally, choose reviewers who have the time and who care enough about you and your career to do a careful review. Your department chairman might have the inclination but does he or she have the time?After 20 years of grant writing, I can still produce wordy, unfocused first draftsUnderstanding what reviewers look for is critical to writing a successful grant application. Try to put yourself in the reviewer&#x27;s shoes. The typical member of a review panel for a government granting agency is a 40-something full professor, faced with his or her own grants, teaching, committees, editorial responsibilities, graduate students, mortgage payments, rebelling teenagers, aging parents, mildewed roses, and so on. These reviewers, always pressed for time and possibly not experts in your field, want to see your main ideas or points at the beginning of the grant application and also near the front of each section.It&#x27;s worth thinking about the way most of us read a scientific paper when you write a grant. Most people read the abstract first, to get an overview of the whole, and the discussion next, to get to the main ideas and conclusions. Reviewers read grant applications with this same attitude. Meet their expectations by providing an abstract or summary that answers the key questions: what are you going to do? why is it worth doing? where will it lead? and (briefly) how are you going to do it?Preparing a grant application differs in several important ways from writing a scientific paper, although we often subconsciously adopt the same style for our grant applications. If you are asked to write a background or rationale section, begin with an overview of the questions or problems you will address and why they are important. The experimental methods section should start with an overview of the experimental design or plan, followed by the details of the methods or techniques. Jumping directly into the methods suggests you care more about techniques than ideas.Choosing the right grant giver, having a good idea that you develop in a clear, focused proposal, and understanding the grant review process enhance your chances but do not guarantee funding. What happens if you don&#x27;t succeed the first time? I find encouragement in the saying \u2018The only people who don&#x27;t make mistakes are the ones who don&#x27;t do anything\u2019. The best scientists occasionally write unfunded proposals, and sometimes dramatically new ideas are harder to get funded than \u2018pretty good\u2019 ones. If your grant fails to get funded the first time, don&#x27;t quit. Revise and resubmit.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;J. Coley &amp; Cynthia A. Scheinberg&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Coley and Scheinberg\u2019s Proposal Writing: Effective Grantsmanship is a strong example of the kind of resource I recommend all MSWs have on their bookshelf: a clear and concise primer on the process of writing a strong grant proposal. The book clearly describes the nuts and bolts of proposal writing, highlights major pitfalls often encountered, and offers sound advice on ways to increase the probability of funding success. The book begins by offering an overview of the major types of funding proposals (government/foundation/corporate) and outlines the major components of a proposal, all along the way offering the reader useful suggestions. In the case of a co-written proposal, for example, the authors recommend assigning a point person responsible for pulling pieces together in time to meet submission deadlines. In the case of a nascent organization, they suggest exploring the possibility of a partnership with a more established agency that might bring more credibility to the initiative. Chapter two offers a brief (and not terribly informative) discussion of the usefulness of technology in finding and evaluating potential funders and sources of data on both the intervention and community. Future editions of the book might highlight AmericanFactFinder, which makes accessing community-level census and American Community Survey data relatively easy. The authors then turn to a discussion of the importance of understanding the agency (to identify strengths and weaknesses), the funder (to identify priorities), and the community (to identify goodness-of-fit). These elements are important not simply for the purposes of writing a strong proposal, but also more critically for effective program development that meets the needs of the community in an accessible manner. Before seeking funding, the authors challenge readers to ask, \u201cIs the service the right one for the client?\u201d (p. 29). After laying the groundwork, the book discusses the major components of the proposal: the needs statement, the goals and objectives, the project narrative, the evaluation plan, the budget, and \u201cfinishing touches\u201d such as the cover letter. Shaefer&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2011,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Administration in Social Work&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/proposal-writing-effective-grantsmanship-soraya-coley-shaefer/aa132f6b40ab5d5a82135ca5852ad458/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/03643107.2011.614542&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;35&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;551 - 552&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:8},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;94 Evaluation of a grant writing workshop designed to increase submission and award rates for career development awards&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;OBJECTIVES/GOALS: To improve early career faculty members\u2019 NIH grant writing skills, Clinical and Translational Science Awards (CTSA) hubs have developed a variety of workshop-style programs. However, few articles have evaluated the impact of grant writing workshops on NIH grant submission and award rates. METHODS/STUDY POPULATION: The K Writing program was developed by the Michigan Institute for Clinical and Health Research (MICHR) at the University of Michigan. Since 2012, 435 scholars have participated in the program. The MICHR K Writing program is a three-part workshop series that prepares scholars by providing them with guidelines to write all sections of a career development grant application. Each session focuses on different sections of the K award proposal. During the workshop sessions, participants break into small groups and exchange drafts of their proposal sections and receive peer critique and feedback from senior faculty facilitators who have experience with NIH study sections. RESULTS/ANTICIPATED RESULTS: Between 2012-2018, 273 scholars participated and 57% were female. Our two primary outcomes of interest are submission rates and success rates (the number of grants awarded divided by the number of applications). We plan to examine the effects of several characteristics, including number of sessions attended, cohort year, and faculty vs. postdoctoral status. We will also examine whether there were differences in submission and success rates between female and male researchers and between underrepresented minority scholars and those who identified as white or Asian. Lastly, we will report submission and success rates for each grant mechanism and compare them to the national averages. DISCUSSION/SIGNIFICANCE: Obtaining external research funding is an important part of a faculty career, especially at its early stages. This research has important implications for the design of similar programs intended to increase submission and success rates for federal grant applications.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Phillip A.
