1715478002.242345, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "tether_quote", "url": "file-8ISwWO1B4Ios5p4J8YVsPgcc", "domain": "WEEK 2 RESOURCE 1.pdf", "text": "\nChapter 4 Peer Justice and Youth Empowerment: An Implementation Guide for Teen Court Programs\n\n40 American Probation and Parole Association\n\nCHAPTER 4\n\nDEVELOPING A PROGRAM PURPOSE, GOALS, AND\nOBJECTIVES\n\n\n\nChapter 4 Peer Justice and Youth Empowerment: An Implementation Guide for Teen Court Programs\n\nAmerican Probation and Parole Association 41\n\nINTRODUCTION\n\nThe number of teen court programs is growing\nrapidly across the country as people realize the\nwide range of youth these programs can\ninfluence and the many benefits associated with\nthem.  With this increasing awareness will come\nincreasing scrutiny, as programs are asked to\nprove their effectiveness while vying for limited\nresources.  It is, therefore, essential that\nprograms identify their purpose, goals, and\nobjectives.  The purpose of a program provides\nthe framework that sets the direction of the\nprogram, while the goals and objectives provide\na plan as to how the purpose will be achieved.\n\nIn addition, the program purpose and goals are\nthe foundation upon which other program\nelements are defined, such as the target\npopulation and program services.  Measurable\nobjectives will provide programs with a\nmechanism for evaluating their results.  Target\npopulation, program services, and program\nevaluation will be discussed in greater detail in\nsubsequent chapters, but they are mentioned\nhere in order to draw attention to the\ninterdependency of the steps and decisions in the\nprogram development process.\n\nWhen developing a program\u2019s purpose, goals,\nand objectives, it may be helpful to understand\nthe rationale and philosophy behind teen court\nprograms.  This chapter begins with a discussion\nof some of the recurring themes among teen\ncourt programs and concludes with practical\ninformation on developing a purpose, goals, and\nobjectives for a teen court program.\nSpecifically, by the end of this chapter, readers\nwill be able to\n\ndiscuss the concept behind the balanced\napproach mission and restorative justice\nmodel and explain its relation to goals of teen\ncourt programs;\n\ndevelop a purpose statement for a teen court\nprogram; and\n\ndevelop short- and long-term goals and\nmeasurable objectives for a teen court\nprogram.\n\nTHE BALANCED APPROACH\nMISSION AND RESTORATIVE\nJUSTICE MODEL\n\nOne of the emerging trends in juvenile justice is\nbased on the concept known as the balanced\napproach mission and restorative justice model.\nIn an attempt to provide equal attention to\noffenders, victims and the community, the\nbalanced approach mission, according to\nBazemore and Umbreit (1994), focuses on\n\naccountability;\n\ncompetency development; and\n\ncommunity protection.\n\nThe philosophy of restorative justice is based on\nthe following values and assumptions\n(McLagan, 1992, as cited in Bazemore and\nUmbreit, 1994):\n\nOffenders, victims, and the community\nshould be included in the response to crime.\n\nGovernment and local communities should\nassume complementary roles in responding\nto crime.\n\nAccountability is based on offenders\nunderstanding the harm caused by their\nactions, accepting responsibility for the harm\ncaused, and making amends.\n\nIt is through values espoused within this type of\nframework that goals of the balanced approach\nmission take on a more significant meaning\n(Bazemore and Umbreit, 1994). What is\ninteresting to note is that these same goals (i.e.,\naccountability, competency development,\ncommunity protection) recur throughout the\nliterature and program materials from teen court\nprograms.  Although they tout goals similar to\n\n\n\nChapter 4 Peer Justice and Youth Empowerment: An Implementation Guide for Teen Court Programs\n\n42 American Probation and Parole Association\n\nthose found in the balanced approach mission,\nthe majority of teen court programs, like many\nother juvenile justice agencies, have not\nimplemented the elements inherent in this\npromising approach to their full potential.\nPrograms that follow a balanced and restorative\njustice model provide a means for reconciling\nthe interests of and meeting the mutual needs of\nvictims, offenders, and the community\n(Bazemore and Umbreit, 1994).\n\nImplementing programs based on the balanced\nand restorative justice model can be an ominous\ntask and often requires agencies to adopt a new\nway of viewing the roles of offenders, victims,\nand the community in the justice process\n(Bazemore and Umbreit, 1994).  With\nconsideration and active participation from other\njuvenile justice agencies, victims, and the\ncommunity, teen court programs can offer\njurisdictions an avenue to bring the philosophy\nof the balanced approach mission in juvenile\njustice into actual practice.\n\nAccountability\nOften society has difficulty determining where\nto affix the culpability for juvenile crime.\nResponsibility has been placed on parents,\nschools, the community, or the court system.\nAlthough each contributes to the problems that\nlead to juvenile crime, the individual\nresponsibility of the youthful offender cannot be\nignored.   Families, schools, communities, and\nthe juvenile justice system all must play a role in\nensuring that youth accept responsibility and are\nheld accountable for their actions.\n\nUnder the balanced approach mission,\naccountability refers to the need for offenders to\nmake amends to victims for the losses caused by\ntheir delinquent actions.  This entails not only\nthe action of making amends through avenues\nsuch as community service or restitution, but\nalso entails creating an awareness in youthful\noffenders of the harmful consequences their\nactions have on others, most notably victims\n(Bazemore, 1993).  In cases coming before a\n\nteen court program in which there is no\nidentifiable victim, the message still should be\nsent to teen court defendants that their actions do\naffect others, including their families and the\ncommunity as a whole.\n\nWhat is missing in many teen court\nprograms, however, is the link for\noffenders between the act of making\namends and the awareness and\nunderstanding of why it is necessary to\nmake amends.\n\nMost teen court programs require youthful\noffenders to redress victims and the community\nfor the harm caused through the provision of\ncommunity service and, in some programs,\nthrough oral or written apologies to victims and\nmonetary restitution (American Probation and\nParole Association, 1994).  What is missing in\nmany teen court programs, however, is the link\nfor offenders between the act of making amends\nand the awareness and understanding of why it is\nnecessary to make amends.  In its Report and\nRecommendations to Victims of Juvenile Crime,\nthe American Correctional Association Victims\nCommittee (1994, p.6) states: \u201cIn far too many\ncases, juvenile offenders leave the scene of their\ncrimes without any inclination of the serious\neffects of their acts or the devastating impact\ntheir crimes have on their victims.\u201d  Therefore,\nif a teen court program is to operationalize the\ngoal of accountability to its fullest extent, it\nmust not only create opportunities for youth to\nrepay victims and the community, it also must\nbuild in an awareness component that educates\nyouth on the impact their actions have on others,\n(i.e., victims and community).\n\nIn doing this, efforts should be made to involve\nthe community and victims actively in the\nprocess (Bazemore and Umbreit, 1994).  The\ncommunity plays significant roles in holding\noffenders accountable by providing locations for\noffenders to complete community service hours\nand by providing offenders with paid work\nopportunities, increasing their ability to pay\nrestitution.  At a minimum, victims should\n\n\n\nChapter 4 Peer Justice and Youth Empowerment: An Implementation Guide for Teen Court Programs\n\nAmerican Probation and Parole Association 43\n\nprovide impact information (written or oral) on\nhow the crime affected them.  This information\ncan be used during the sentencing phase to\nprovide jurors with information to assist them in\ndetermining an appropriate sentence and to\nbegin the process of personalizing the crime for\nthe offender.\n\nCompetency Development\nUnder the balanced approach mission, the\ncompetency development goal emphasizes the\nneed for offenders to leave the juvenile justice\nsystem with skills that will enable them to be\nproductive participants in society (Bazemore\nand Umbreit, 1994).  Additionally, Norem-\nHebeisen and Hedin (1981) stress that to\ndecrease delinquency, one goal of peer\nprograms should be to provide at-risk youth\nwith skills that aid them when they find\nthemselves in situations in which problem\nbehavior is encouraged and supported.  Teen\ncourt programs can be effective in this area by\nteaching youth (i.e., youthful offenders and\ncommunity youth) necessary life and coping\nskills and then offering a meaningful forum in\nwhich to use and refine those skills.\n\nThe goal is for young people to carry\nover and apply what they learn through\nteen court when confronted with other\ndifficult choices and situations in their\nlives.\n\nThroughout their participation in the program,\nteen court defendants and youth volunteers will\nbe confronted by persons with differing\nviewpoints and backgrounds, which often\nmirror experiences and situations encountered in\nother aspects of their lives.  At times, these\ndifferences may cause frustration; however, the\nway youth learn to react and respond to these\ndiffering viewpoints and personalities is all part\nof the learning process.  The goal is for young\npeople to carry over and apply what they learn\nthrough teen court when confronted with other\ndifficult choices and situations in their lives.\n\nMost teen court programs are designed to\nintervene early (usually after a first offense) in\nthe delinquent behavior of a juvenile.  Some\nways in which teen court programs offer skill-\nbuilding opportunities for youthful offenders is\nthrough requiring the performance of\ncommunity service and participation in\neducational workshops.  In addition to holding\nyouth accountable, basic habits that the\nperformance of community service can instill in\nyouth include (Maloney and Bazemore, 1994)\n\nreporting to work on time;\n\ncooperating with coworkers;\n\naccepting constructive criticism; and\n\nsuccessfully finishing a task.\n\nEducational workshops can be designed and\noffered to defendants to assist them in\ndeveloping needed skills in specific areas, such\nas managing conflict and problem solving.  As a\nmeans to further the development, enhancement,\nand application of life skills, most teen court\nprograms require or encourage offenders to\nparticipate as a volunteer in the program, usually\nin the role of a juror.  The table is turned, and the\ndelinquent youth is offered an opportunity to\nexperience the other side of the justice system\nby determining consequences for a peer.  Staff,\nwho observe a youth\u2019s interaction with other\njurors and teen court participants, can identify\nyouth who are lacking in certain skill areas and\nwho may need additional assistance or an\ninformal referral for other services.\n\nTeen court is not a mock trial; the cases that are\nheard are real.  As a prevention program, teen\ncourt programs offer youth in the community\nvaluable education and hands-on experience in\nthe legal and judicial system.   This places youth\nvolunteers in positions that require a tremendous\namount of responsibility.  They assume roles\nthat give them the power to make decisions that\ncan have a direct impact on the lives of the teen\ncourt defendants.  Through these roles, young\n\n\n\nChapter 4 Peer Justice and Youth Empowerment: An Implementation Guide for Teen Court Programs\n\n44 American Probation and Parole Association\n\nThe Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency\nPrevention (1993) based a major component of\nits Comprehensive Strategy for Serious, Violent,\nand Chronic Juvenile Offenders on the premise\nthat to effectively handle delinquent behavior,\nthere must to be a range of graduated sanctions\nand a full continuum of treatment and\nrehabilitative services.  Aside from assisting\ncommunity youth to develop needed skills to\nresist the pressures to participate in illegal\nactivity, teen court programs promote public\nsafety by offering jurisdictions an alternative\nprogram to juvenile court for nonviolent,\nmisdemeanor cases.  The rationale for doing so\nis that the number of cases being heard in\njuvenile court will decrease, and more time will\nbe allotted for juvenile court to hear more\nserious cases.\n\nSAMPLE STATEMENTS OF\nPURPOSE, GOALS, AND\nOBJECTIVES\n\nAfter considering the philosophy and rationale\nbehind teen courts, program developers need to\ntranslate the philosophy into practice.  Each\n\npeople can play an active part in addressing the\nproblem of juvenile delinquency within their\ncommunity.\n\nCommunity Protection\nThe right of the public to a safe and secure\ncommunity is at the heart of all justice programs\nin both the adult and juvenile systems.  As a\nmeans to help ensure public safety, the balanced\napproach mission calls for a shared\nresponsibility between the juvenile justice\nsystem and the community for the control and\nreintegration of offenders (Bazemore and\nUmbreit, 1994).  By helping youth develop and\nenhance needed life and coping skills and\neducating them on the legal and judicial system,\nteen court programs can cause youth to adopt\nmore prosocial attitudes, which ultimately can\nhelp protect the community.\n\nThis concept is illustrated by the personal\nstatement in Figure 4-1.  It was written by a 15-\nyear-old girl who, before her involvement as a\nvolunteer in the Buncombe County Teen Court\nProgram in Asheville, North Carolina, had\ndeveloped a pattern of shoplifting.  She was\nnever caught.\n\nFigure 4-1: Personal Statement of a Youth Teen Court Volunteer\n\nA few years ago I started hanging out with some guys that always got into trouble with the police. I knew\nwhat they were doing was wrong, but I didn\u2019t know exactly what would happen if we were caught. It\ndidn\u2019t take long for me to get used to their ways and fit in well. When we would go into a store, I always\nknew my part, and no one else ever messed up either. We never got caught, and after a while we all got\nvery cocky about things.\n\nThere was one time when we went into a store five times in a row, and the last two times there was a\npolice officer in there. It didn\u2019t bother us; we just tried to get as much as we could and if we got caught,\nwell, really we thought that the police were too stupid to catch us. The way we thought was an ignorant\nway of thinking, because a week after that my friends were caught at another store, I, fortunately, was not\nwith them, but it got me to thinking. What if I had been with them? If I had been caught, what would have\nhappened? Even though it got me thinking, I didn\u2019t quit doing those types of things. I still wasn\u2019t sure\nwhat could happen if I was caught.\n\nOnce teen court started in Asheville, I got into it. I learned about what could have happened if I was\ncaught, and that was when I decided not to do anything illegal again. If it hadn\u2019t been for teen court, I\nwould never have learned about the consequences of doing wrong things and I would probably still be\ndoing them.\n\n\n\nChapter 4 Peer Justice and Youth Empowerment: An Implementation Guide for Teen Court Programs\n\nAmerican Probation and Parole Association 45\n\njurisdiction should consider the philosophy\nwithin the context of its own community needs\nand resources.  Blindly implementing a program\nbased on its apparent success in other\njurisdictions is a simplistic solution that\nultimately may prove ineffective (Cochran,\n1989).\n\nBlindly implementing a program based\non its apparent success in other\njurisdictions is a simplistic solution\nthat ultimately may prove ineffective\n(Cochran, 1989).\n\nIt is advisable to include agency staff and\nstakeholders of the program (those who are\nsupportive of the program\u2019s efforts as well as\nthose who may be resistant) in the process of\ndeveloping the purpose, goals, and objectives.  If\na program is being developed within an existing\nagency, the program purpose must be in\naccordance with all other aspects of the\noverseeing agency\u2019s mission and must be\nacceptable to all involved with the program.\nAccording to Crowe and Schaefer (1992), some\nissues that may need to be evaluated by program\ndevelopers in this process include\n\nthe overall mission of the agency\nimplementing the program;\n\nlegal issues that may affect the program; and\n\nlimitations of community and program\nresources.\n\nThe following section outlines the process of\ndeveloping a program\u2019s purpose, goals, and\nobjectives.  When possible, examples used\nreflect concepts related to the earlier discussion\nof the balanced approach mission and restorative\njustice model.\n\nProgram Purpose\nA teen court program\u2019s viability depends on its\nability to address a pressing local problem.  It is\ncrucial that a teen court program focus on needs\nwithin its jurisdiction that can be addressed\n\nrealistically.  This will enable agencies to\ndevelop manageable, effective programs.  The\nfollowing two primary questions can help\nprogram developers limit the scope of a program\nto something that is realistic and achievable\n(Fulton, Stone, and Gendreau, 1994):\n\nWhat deficiencies are we trying to\novercome?\n\nWhich ones can we realistically overcome\ngiven the existing resources and level of\nsupport?\n\nA clearly articulated statement identifying the\nprimary purpose of the program will assist\nagencies in remaining focused on achievable and\ncongruent goals.  The purpose statement for any\nprogram, like an agency mission statement,\nshould clearly state the primary purpose of the\nprogram and the population for whom it is\ndesigned.  It also should include a very brief and\ngeneral description of the services it will provide\n(Fulton, Stone, and Gendreau, 1994).  A sample\nteen court purpose statement may be found in\nFigure 4-2.\n\nFigure 4-2: Sample Teen Court Program Purpose\nStatement\n\nThe Teen Court Program is a community-\nbased intervention/prevention program\ndesigned to provide an alternative response for\nthe juvenile justice system for first-time,\nnonviolent, misdemeanor juvenile offenders,\nin which community youth determine the\nappropriate sanctions for the offender. The\nprogram will hold youthful offenders\naccountable and provide educational services\nto offenders and youth volunteers in an effort\nto promote long-term behavioral change that\nleads to enhanced public safety.\n\nProgram Goals\nProgram goals are broad, general statements that\nserve to map out the future and provide a\nmeasure of success in achieving the program\n\n\n\nChapter 4 Peer Justice and Youth Empowerment: An Implementation Guide for Teen Court Programs\n\n46 American Probation and Parole Association\n\npurpose.  They should clarify the intentions of\nthe program and direct program activities.  It is\nrecommended that agencies apply the following\nguidelines when developing goals for teen court\nprograms:\n\nFocus the goals according to the target\npopulation and program services provided.\n\nCarefully select the goals of a teen court\nprogram based on prioritized needs and\navailable resources.\n\nDifferentiate short- and long-term goals.\n\nA further discussion of these guidelines reveals\nhow their application can enhance the credibility\nof teen court programs.\n\nFocusing on Target Population and Services\nto Be Provided\nWhen developing goals, program developers\nshould keep in mind the target population the\nprogram is designed to serve.  If a program\ndecides to target first-time offenders, the goals\nand objectives of the program may differ from\nthose of programs targeting repeat offenders\nwho may need more intensive services.  Target\npopulation and program services are discussed\nin more detail in subsequent chapters.\n\nBasing Goals on Prioritized Needs and\nAvailable Resources\nStakeholder desires and jurisdictional needs\nshould not be ignored.  However, agencies must\nexamine and prioritize these needs.  This\nrequires an examination of the needs of youth in\nthe community and a determination of which\nneeds are not currently being met through other\nmeans and could be met through teen court.\nFunding and community resources need to be\nexamined to ascertain if the identified needs can\nbe met with existing resources or if the\ndevelopment of resources is feasible.  Realistic\ngoals that address a specific and important need\nthen can be established. (See Figure 4-3.)\n\nFigure 4-3: Sample Teen Court Program Goals -\nBased on a Prioritized Need\n\nPrioritized Need: A program to address the\nproblem of underage drinking and illegal drug\nuse in the community.\n\nLong-term goal: To decrease the number of\nyouth in the community\nengaging in alcohol and\nillegal drug use.\n\nShort-term goal: To intervene early, provide\neducation to, and promote\nawareness among youth of\nthe dangers of substance\nabuse.\n\nDifferentiating Between Short- and Long-\nTerm Goals\nProgram developers may find it helpful to\ndifferentiate between short- and long-term goals\nof the teen court program.  Some goals may\nhave a rehabilitative focus associated with long-\nterm behavior change. These may be easier to\nevaluate if refocused and broken down into\nshort-term goals that support the long-term goal.\nAlso, it may be easier to sustain internal and\nexternal program support if people can see goals\nbeing achieved in the short-term.  Figure 4-4\nprovides an example.\n\nFigure 4-4: Sample Teen Court Program Long- and\nShort-Term Goals\n\nLong-term goal: Improve the capacity of\nyouth to become\nresponsible and productive\ncitizens.\n\nShort-term goal: Provide youth with education\nand hands-on experience in\nthe judical systems.\n\nShort-term goal: Increase life and coping skills\nof youth in the community.\n\nLong-term goal: Protect the community.\n\nShort-term goal: Hold youthful offenders\naccountable.\n\n\n\nChapter 4 Peer Justice and Youth Empowerment: An Implementation Guide for Teen Court Programs\n\nAmerican Probation and Parole Association 47\n\nProgram Objectives\nObjectives are crucial to effective program\nimplementation and evaluation.  Program\nobjectives specify how program goals will be\nachieved and should include a method for\nevaluating results.  While program goals should\nclearly state the intentions of a program,\nobjectives should describe the mechanisms and\nstrategies used to accomplish those intentions.\n\nSpecific and measurable objectives should be\nassigned to each major goal area.  Objectives\nshould be achieved within a limited time and be\nidentified with an actual result.  It is\nrecommended that teen court objectives be\nresult-oriented rather than activity-oriented\n(Crowe and Schaefer, 1992; Fulton, Stone, and\nGendreau, 1994).  Some sample goals and\nobjectives may be found in Figure 4-5.\n\nFigure 4-5: Sample Teen Court Program Goals and Objectives\n\nLong-term goal: Improve the capacity of youth to become responsible and productive citizens.\n\nShort-term goal: Provide youth with education and hands-on experience in the judicial system.\n\nobjective 1: 90% of youth attending the five-week teen court training seminar will pass a teen court bar\nexam.\n\nobjective 2: All youth volunteers will be scheduled to participate in a teen court trial/hearing within\nthree months of passing their bar examination.\n\nShort-term goal: Increase life and coping skills of youth in the community.\n\nobjective 1: 30% of the ongoing youth volunteer pool will consist of past teen court defendants by the\nend of fiscal year 1996.\n\nobjective 2: 85% of youth volunteers will complete a six-week life skills class during fiscal year 1996.\n\nLong-term goal: Protect the community.\n\nShort-term goal: Hold youthful offenders accountable.\n\nobjective 1: All referrals to the teen court program will be docketed and heard in teen court within five\nweeks of the referral.\n\nobjective 2: During fiscal year 1996, 80% of teen court defendants will successfully complete their\ncommunity service hours within 90 days of their sentence.\n\nobjective 3: 80% of all restitution payments scheduled to be made during fiscal year 1996 will be\ncollected.\n\nobjective 4: During fiscal year 1996, 60% of teen court defendants will complete a four-week victim\nawareness class.\n\nLong-term goal: Decrease the number of youth in the community engaging in alcohol and illegal drug\nuse.\n\nShort-term goal: Intervene early, provide education to, and promote awareness among youth of the\ndangers of substance abuse.\n\nobjective 1: During fiscal year 1996, 95% of all teen court defendants charged with an alcohol/drug\noffense will attend a Mothers Against Drunk Driving victim impact panel.\n\nobjective 2: 80% of all teen court defendants will successfully complete a four-week substance abuse\nawareness program.\n\nobjective 3: A pretest and three-month followup test (designed to assess change in knowledge and\nattitude about alcohol and drug use among adolescents) will be administered to all\nparticipants of the substance abuse awareness program. 80% of participants will show a\npositive change in knowledge and attitude relative to alcohol and drug use.\n\n\n\nChapter 4 Peer Justice and Youth Empowerment: An Implementation Guide for Teen Court Programs\n\n48 American Probation and Parole Association\n\nCONCLUSION\n\nThe establishment of a program\u2019s purpose,\ngoals, and objectives is critical to effective\nprogram implementation and evaluation.\nWithout a carefully considered purpose and\ngoals, the program will lack a clear direction\nand eventually may find its existence called into\nquestion.\n\nThe sample purpose, goals, and objectives\nprovided in this chapter are based on the earlier\n\ndiscussion of the balanced approach mission.\nIndividual teen court programs should develop\nrealistic and achievable goals that reflect the\nprogram\u2019s philosophical basis, jurisdictional\ndifferences, and target population.  Establishing\nreasonable goals and objectives will require\nmore work during the planning and development\nstages to ascertain what improvement rates are\nachievable, given the program aims and\nresources.  However, this investment of time and\neffort should pay off in the long run with a more\neffective program.\n\n\n\nChapter 4 Peer Justice and Youth Empowerment: An Implementation Guide for Teen Court Programs\n\nAmerican Probation and Parole Association 49\n\nCHECKLIST FOR PROGRAM PURPOSE, GOALS, AND OBJECTIVES\n\nHave teen court program organizers or staff \u2014\n\n\u2751 Developed an understanding of the balanced approach mission and the restorative justice\nmodel?\n\nHoward Zehr (1990, pp. 230-231) developed the following \u201cRestorative Justice Yardstick\u201d as a\nmeans for providing juvenile justice agencies with guidance in moving closer to values and\npolicies consistent with the restorative justice model.  These questions should be examined\nwhile keeping in mind the objectives of the balanced approach mission (i.e., accountability,\ncompetency development, community protection).\n\n\u2751 Do victims experience justice?\n\n\u2751 Are there sufficient opportunities for them to tell their truth to relevant listeners?\n\u2751 Are they receiving needed compensation or restitution?\n\u2751 Is the injustice adequately acknowledged?\n\u2751 Are they sufficiently protected against further violation?\n\u2751 Does the outcome adequately reflect the severity of the offense?\n\u2751 Are they receiving adequate information about the event, the offender, and the\n\nprocess?\n\u2751 Do they have a voice in the process?\n\u2751 Is the experience of justice adequately public?\n\u2751 Do they have adequate support from others?\n\u2751 Are their families receiving adequate assistance and support?\n\u2751 Are other needs \u2014 material, psychological, spiritual \u2014 being addressed?\n\n\u2751 Do offenders experience justice?\n\n\u2751 Are they encouraged to understand and take responsibility for what they have\ndone?\n\n\u2751 Are misattributions challenged?\n\u2751 Are they provided encouragement and opportunity to make things right?\n\u2751 Are they given the opportunity to participate in the process?\n\u2751 Is there encouragement toward changed behavior (repentance)?\n\u2751 Is there a mechanism for monitoring or verifying changes?\n\u2751 Are their own needs being addressed?\n\u2751 Are their families receiving support and assistance?\n\n\u2751 Is the victim-offender relationship addressed?\n\n\u2751 Is there opportunity for a meeting, if appropriate \u2014 either direct or therapeutic?\n\u2751 Is there opportunity and encouragement for an exchange of information \u2014 about\n\nthe event, about one another?\n\u2751 Are misattributions being challenged?\n\n\n\nChapter 4 Peer Justice and Youth Empowerment: An Implementation Guide for Teen Court Programs\n\n50 American Probation and Parole Association\n\n\u2751 Are community concerns being taken into account?\n\n\u2751 Is the process and outcome sufficiently public?\n\u2751 Is community protection being addressed?\n\u2751 Is there need for some restitution or symbolic action for the community?\n\u2751 Is the community represented in some way in the process?\n\n\u2751 Is the future being addressed?\n\n\u2751 Is there provision for solving the problems that led up to this event?\n\u2751 Is there provision for solving problems caused by this event?\n\u2751 Have future intentions been addressed?\n\u2751 Is there provision for monitoring, verifying, and troubleshooting outcomes?\n\n\u2751 Developed a purpose statement?\n\n\u2751 Determined the deficiencies or areas of need within the community? (Note: Refer to the\nneeds and resources assessment discussed in Chapter 2.)\n\n\u2751 Determined which deficiencies or areas of need can be realistically addressed.\n\u2751 Determined who the program is designed to serve? (Note: Chapter 5 discusses\n\ndetermining a target population in more detail.)\n\u2751 Decided what services will be provided by this program? (Note:  Chapter 6 discusses\n\ndesigning program services in more detail.)\n\n\u2751 Developed program goals?\n\n\u2751 Developed goals that focus on the target population to be served and the program services\nto be provided?\n\n\u2751 Categorized goals according to short- and long-term goals?\n\u2751 Prioritized goals according to needs and available resources?\n\n\u2751 Developed program objectives?\n\n\u2751 Developed objectives that specify how the program goals will be achieved?\n\u2751 Developed objectives that include a method for evaluating results?\n\u2751 Established a time frame within which the objectives will be achieved?\n\u2751 Defined objectives that are results-oriented, rather than activity-oriented?\n\n\n", "title": "WEEK 2 RESOURCE 1.pdf", "tether_id": null}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"command": "context_stuff", "is_visually_hidden_from_conversation": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4", "parent_id": "114941c1-7df5-47cc-bfd2-6f6fa27d917b", "request_id": "8826b191cdfc839a-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "114941c1-7df5-47cc-bfd2-6f6fa27d917b", "children": ["9fa6fd07-d6f8-4c73-88e8-dc8bcc3a12d6"]}, "9fa6fd07-d6f8-4c73-88e8-dc8bcc3a12d6": {"id": "9fa6fd07-d6f8-4c73-88e8-dc8bcc3a12d6", "message": {"id": "9fa6fd07-d6f8-4c73-88e8-dc8bcc3a12d6", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1715478002.242486, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["### Part A: Differences Between a Program&#x27;s Purpose, Goals, and Objectives\n\nWhen developing a program, especially for grant applications, it&#x27;s crucial to clearly distinguish between the program&#x27;s purpose, goals, and objectives. These components serve as critical building blocks in presenting a well-thought-out proposal to potential funders.\n\n1. **Purpose**: The purpose of a program provides the foundational framework that sets the overall direction. It defines the broad aim of the program and answers why it exists. The purpose is essential in grant writing as it communicates the core essence and justification of the program to funders, helping them understand the overarching intent behind the initiative\u30107\u2020source\u3011.\n\n2. **Goals**: Goals are broad, general statements that articulate the desired outcomes the program aims to achieve in the long run. They map out the future and provide a measure of success. Goals are essential in grants because they demonstrate the strategic endpoints of the program, giving funders a clear picture of the intended impact and aligning with their interests and priorities\u30107\u2020source\u3011.\n\n3. **Objectives**: Objectives are specific, measurable steps that outline how the goals will be achieved. They are concise and detailed, often including specific targets and timelines. Objectives are crucial in grant proposals because they provide measurable benchmarks for evaluating the program&#x27;s success and accountability, ensuring that there are concrete criteria against which the program&#x27;s effectiveness can be assessed\u30107\u2020source\u3011.\n\n### Part B: Grant Proposal Description for CLU Social Impact Innovation Fund\n\nIn pursuit of enhancing societal well-being, I propose to establish the &quot;Global Happiness Initiative Foundation&quot; (GHIF). This foundation aims to elevate individuals&#x27; quality of life worldwide through comprehensive access to education, healthcare, travel opportunities, and mental health resources. By focusing on these critical areas, GHIF seeks to promote long-term happiness and well-being without the restrictions typically imposed by health conditions. This initiative will operate as a community and global cooperative effort, emphasizing inclusivity and universal benefit. Through strategic partnerships and innovative service delivery, GHIF intends to make a significant impact by transforming lives and fostering a more joyful and connected world.\n\n### Part C: Defining the Program/Idea with Purpose, Goals, and Objectives\n\n1. **Purpose**: The purpose of the Global Happiness Initiative Foundation is to enhance the overall well-being and happiness of individuals globally by providing unrestricted access to essential life-enhancing services such as education, healthcare, and mental wellness resources.\n\n2. **Goals**: \n   - **Long-term Goal**: To significantly increase the global population&#x27;s access to key well-being services, thereby improving quality of life and happiness.\n   - **Short-term Goal**: To establish and strengthen partnerships with local and international organizations to facilitate service delivery and reach a wider audience.\n\n3. **Objectives**:\n   - **Objective 1**: By the end of the first year, launch educational programs in at least three countries, benefiting over 10,000 individuals.\n   - **Objective 2**: Within the first six months, partner with at least five major healthcare providers to offer comprehensive health services with an emphasis on preventive care and mental health.\n   - **Objective 3**: Develop and implement a scalable model for wellness travel that can be replicated across different regions, evaluated through participant satisfaction and repeat engagement rates."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true
